{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Louis Osborne Coxe | image = | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = April 15, 1918 | birth_place = [[Manchester, New Hampshire]] | death_date = May 25, 1993 (age 75) | death_place = [[Augusta, Maine]] | occupation = Author, poet, professor, playwright | nationality = United States | spouse = Edith Winsor | education = [[St. Paul's School (New Hampshire)|St. Paul's School]]
[[Princeton University]] | genre = | subject = | movement = | signature = | website = }} '''Louis Osborne Coxe''' (April 15, 1918 – May 25, 1993) was an American poet, playwright, essayist, and professor who was recognized by the [[Academy of American Poets]] for his "long, powerful, quiet accomplishment, largely unrecognized, in lyric poetry." He was probably best known for his dramatic adaptation of [[Herman Melville]]'s ''[[Billy Budd]]'', which opened on Broadway in 1951. ==Biography== Born in [[Manchester, New Hampshire]] in 1918 but raised in [[Salem, Massachusetts]] (where his family had lived since 1640), Coxe was educated at [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)|St. Paul's School]]. He graduated from [[Princeton University]] in 1940, writing his senior thesis on [[Edwin Arlington Robinson]]. During [[World War II]], Coxe served in the [[United States Navy]], commanding the U.S.S. PC-549 in the [[Pacific Ocean theater of World War II|South Pacific Theater]] during the Northern [[Solomon Islands campaign]] and the [[invasion of Guam]] and [[invasion of Saipan]]-Tinian (and later the U.S.S. PC-1195), an experience that would shape much of his poetry. After leaving active service in 1946, he married Edith Winsor, granddaughter of Boston financier [[Robert Winsor]], and began teaching at Princeton. He was Briggs-Copeland Fellow at [[Harvard University]] from 1948 to 1949, and from 1949 to 1955, he taught at the [[University of Minnesota]]. Coxe then moved to [[Bowdoin College]] in [[Brunswick, Maine]] in 1956, where he remained (except for brief appointments at [[Trinity College, Dublin]], Ireland, and the [[University of Aix-Marseilles]], France) as head of the English department until his death in 1993 after 11 years suffering from [[Alzheimer's disease]]. Coxe received his largest critical recognition for his dramatic adaptation, with [[Robert H. Chapman (writer)|Robert Chapman]], of [[Herman Melville]]'s morality tale [[Billy Budd]], which opened to critical acclaim on Broadway in 1951, winning both the [[Donaldson Awards]] and the [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] for best play. The [[New York Times]]' [[Brooks Atkinson]] called it "extraordinarily well done," and said that "the tragic portions are written with taste, firmness and intelligence." Coxe was also credited with co-writing the screenplay for [[Peter Ustinov]]'s film version of the play. He wrote several other plays, most for local productions in Maine, one of which, "Decoration Day" (about Civil War general [[Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain]]), was published as a book along with his long narrative poem "Nikal Seyn." He was also praised for his criticism, writing books on both [[Chaucer]] and [[Edwin Arlington Robinson]]. But Coxe's main focus was his poetry, which U.S. Poet Laureate [[Howard Nemerov]] called "terse, cryptic, almost savage in their beauty." Much of his work focused on his experience during World War II and the natural environment of his native New England. Several of his poems, reviews and essays appeared first in [[The New Yorker]], [[The New Republic]], [[Paris Review]], and [[Atlantic Monthly]]. In 1972 the [[Maine Arts Commission|Maine State Commission on the Arts and Humanities]] presented him with a Maine State Award for his significant contributions to the cultural life of Maine. He was named the 36th fellow of the [[Academy of American Poets]] in 1977 and was awarded a creative writing grant from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] that same year. One of the last poems he published, "Nightsong" (1983), was featured in the anthology ''Fifty Years of American Poetry''. ==Bibliography== ===Poetry=== * ''The Sea Faring and Other Poems'' (1947) * ''The Second Man and Other Poems'' (1955) * ''The Wilderness and Other Poems'' (1958) * ''The Middle Passage'' (1960) * ''The Last Hero and Other Poems'' (1965) * ''Nikal Seyn & Decoration Day: A Poem and a Play'' (1966) * ''Passage: Selected Poems 1943–1978'' (1979) * ''The North Well'' (1985) ===Plays=== * ''Billy Budd'' (1949) * ''Nikal Seyn & Decoration Day: A Poem and a Play'' (1966) * ''Birth of a State'' ===Criticism=== * ''Chaucer,'' part of the Laurel Poetry Series (editor, along with introduction and notes) (1963) * ''Edwin Arlington Robinson; The Life of Poetry'' (1969) * ''Enabling Acts: Selected Essays in Criticism'' (1976) ==Awards== * [[Donaldson Awards]] Best Play, 1951 * [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] Best Play, 1951 * [[Maine State Award]], 1972 * [[National Endowment for the Arts]] creative writing grant, 1977 * [[Academy of American Poets]] Fellowship, 1977 ==External links== * [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE0DB1330F93BA15756C0A965958260 Louis O. Coxe, 75; His Poems Reflected New England Roots, by Marvine Howe. New York Times, May 28, 1993]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110811181312/http://archives.sps.edu/common/text.asp?Img=22274&Keyword=&Headline=&Author=&SearchMode=0 Obituary: Louis Osborne Coxe. Saint Paul's School Alumni Horae Autumn 1993, Volume 73, Issue 3, Page 223]. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coxe, Louis Osborne}} [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:Writers from Manchester, New Hampshire]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Fellows]] [[Category:Poets from Maine]] [[Category:Bowdoin College faculty]] [[Category:Writers from Brunswick, Maine]] [[Category:Gardiner family]] [[Category:20th-century American poets]] [[Category:20th-century American dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:American male dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:American male poets]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]]

The '''Master of Counselling''' or '''Counseling''' ('''MC''', '''M.C.''', or '''M.Couns.''') is a postgraduate [[professional degree]]. The degree prepares students for professional practice as counsellors or counselling psychologists in mental health clinics, community organizations, schools, post-secondary educational institutions, employee assistance programs, and private practice. Students typically choose a specialization, such as [[Counseling psychology|counselling psychology]], school counselling, marital & couples counselling, career counselling, or [[art therapy]].
==Country-specific information==
===Australia=== A number of Australian universities, including [[La Trobe University]], [[University of Queensland|The University of Queensland]], [[Victoria University, Australia|Victoria University]], [[Monash University]], and [[Curtin University]], offer a Master of Counselling degree.<ref>{{cite web|title=Master of Counselling (MCouns)|url=http://www.uq.edu.au/study/program.html?acad_prog=5333|work=University of Queensland - Courses and programmes|accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Master of Counselling, Victoria University|url=http://www.vu.edu.au/courses/master-of-counselling-ampe}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Master in Counselling, Monash University|url=http://www.monash.edu.au/study/coursefinder/course/3236/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Master of Counselling, Curtin University|url=http://handbook.curtin.edu.au/courses/31/311204.html}}</ref>
===Canada=== The degree is awarded by a number of Canadian universities such as the [[University of Calgary]], the [[University of Lethbridge]], and [[Athabasca University]]. The degree meets academic requirements to attain registration as a Canadian Certified Counsellor (CCC) with the Canadian Counselling and Psychotherapy Association or Registered Psychologist (R.Psych) in certain Canadian provinces, including Alberta. <ref>Graduate Programs in Education, https://www.ucalgary.ca/gpe/programs/master-counselling-mc-campus</ref><ref>Faculty of Education, Programs Offered, {{cite web |url=http://www.uleth.ca/edu/master-counselling/programs |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908055939/http://www.uleth.ca/edu/master-counselling/programs |archivedate=2011-09-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>MC Program Requirements, http://calendar.athabascau.ca/grad/counsel_01_05.php</ref>
===New Zealand=== The [[University of Waikato]] offers a Master of Counselling degree.<ref>{{cite web|title=Master of Counselling(MCouns)|url=http://calendar.waikato.ac.nz/regulations/masters/mcouns.html}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== The [[University of Edinburgh]] offers a Master of Counselling (Interpersonal Dialogue) as a two-year full-time course.<ref>{{cite web|title=Master of Counselling (Interpersonal Dialogue): Overview|url=http://www.ed.ac.uk/schools-departments/health/counselling/study/programmes/master-counselling-id/overview|work=University of Edinburgh|accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref>
===United States=== [[Idaho State University]] is among United States institutions offering a Master of Counseling (one "L" in US spelling).<ref>{{cite web|title=Program Profile: Master of Counseling|url=http://www.isu.edu/hpcounsl/ Idaho State University|accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref>

{{URL|https://mormonleaks.io}} | remarks = | formerly = MormonWikiLeaks | footnotes = }} '''MormonLeaks''' (formerly '''Mormon WikiLeaks''') is a [[whistleblowing]] organization inspired by [[WikiLeaks]], which focuses on exposing documents from the leadership of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church). It began in October 2016 as a leaked series of videos on the [[YouTube]] channel '''Mormon Leaks'''. In total, 15 videos were initially leaked via the Mormon Leaks channel from meetings of high-ranking LDS leaders including the [[Quorum of the Twelve]]. They discussed topics including the "[[homosexual agenda]]", the [[subprime mortgage crisis]], and a debate over the [[sexual orientation]] of [[Chelsea Manning]]. Politicians featured in the videos included former Utah governor [[Mike Leavitt]] and former U.S. Senator from Oregon [[Gordon H. Smith]].
Ryan McKnight, founder of MormonLeaks, was interviewed by ''[[The New York Times]]'' about his YouTube channel Mormon Leaks, and this led to contacts from [[Reddit]] who asked him for a secure way to send files. He set up a website to allow whistleblowers to protect their [[anonymity]]. The submission process ensures [[confidentiality]], including erasure of [[IP address|IP addresses]], asking leakers to use the privacy browser [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]], sending documents via [[SecureDrop]], and additional [[encryption]] methods. Initial funding was raised through [[GoFundMe]], and an official [[Twitter]] account was set up. The site's intent is to increase transparency of LDS Church leadership, and would not leak names of lower-level employees, instead focusing on the Quorum of the Twelve and the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]].
[[University of Tampa]] professor Ryan Cragun said scholars were interested in finding out what documents would be revealed, noting there was a dearth of information available about the [[Finances of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|finances of the LDS Church]]. He said active Mormons were unlikely to view the leaked materials, but the material would have a more significant impact on those who were questioning or had already resigned their membership status. Mormon scholar and columnist [[Jana Riess]] gave a mixed assessment, criticizing their tactics regarding privacy while saying it could help to increase LDS Church leadership transparency. Utah attorney and Mormon blogger Steve Evans said the practice of leaking was criminal publication of stolen property, and said LDS Church employees who leaked material were likely violating a [[non-disclosure agreements|non-disclosure agreement]].
==Organization== ===Beginnings on YouTube === [[File:LDS Conference Center-up.jpg|thumb|Videos were posted to the YouTube channel Mormon Leaks on the last day of the October 2016 LDS [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]].<ref name=mattcanham /><ref name=conferenceweekend />]]
Ryan McKnight, the site's founder, had previously gained attention in October 2016 when he was interviewed by ''[[The New York Times]]'' about his [[YouTube]] channel ''Mormon Leaks'', which released videos of top LDS leadership executive discussions.<ref name=leakedvideos>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/07/us/mormon-videos-leaked.html|accessdate=December 20, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Leaked Videos Pull Back Curtain on Mormon Leadership|first=Laurie|last=Goodstein|date=October 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name="chandler">{{citation|last=Chandler|first=Michael Alison|title=Former church member launches ‘Mormon Wikileaks’ for anonymous sharing of documents and videos|date=December 20, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2016/12/20/mormon-wikileaks-launched-by-former-church-member|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/religion/former-church-member-launches-mormon-wikileaks-site-our-goal-is-pure-and-simple-transparency|title=Former church member launches 'Mormon Wikileaks' site: 'Our goal is, pure and simple, transparency'|newspaper=National Post|access-date=2016-12-28}}</ref> McKnight is a former Mormon, having resigned from the LDS Church in 2014,<ref name="chandler" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=exmormoncreates /> residing in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]].<ref name=newwebsiteplans>{{citation|url=http://www.sltrib.com/lifestyle/faith/4725913-155/new-website-plans-to-showcase-leaked|accessdate=December 20, 2016|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|title=New website plans to showcase leaked Mormon documents|first=Peggy Fletcher|last=Stack|date=December 17, 2016}}</ref><ref name=mandyvelez>{{citation|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/former-church-member-launches-mormon-wikileaks-a7487536.html|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=December 20, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|first=Mandy|last=Velez|title=Former church member launches ‘Mormon Wikileaks’ for anonymous tips and whistleblowers}}</ref> The anonymous individual who sent him the videos via email, according to McKnight, had been holding onto them for a period of years but with the intention to do something with them eventually.<ref name=notapproval /><ref name=manbehind>{{citation|url=http://fox13now.com/2016/10/03/man-behind-postings-of-lds-church-leaked-videos-says-clips-were-anonymously-emailed-to-him/|title=Man behind postings of LDS Church leaked videos says clips were anonymously emailed to him|first1=Tiffany|last1=Demasters|first2=Jeff|last2=McAdam|date=October 3, 2016|accessdate=December 21, 2016|work=[[KSTU]]}}</ref> Within a time span of under a month the YouTube channel had garnered 2,200 followers.<ref name=alexjohnson />
The LDS Church did not publicly question the veracity of the videos,<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> which included top leadership debating the "[[homosexual agenda]]".<ref name=alexthompson>{{citation|url=https://news.vice.com/article/mormon-church-leaders-discuss-homosexual-agenda-in-leaked-videos|accessdate=December 20, 2016|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|first=Alex|last=Thompson|title=Mormon church leaders discuss 'homosexual agenda' in leaked videos|date=October 3, 2016}}</ref> Additional topics discussed by the high-level LDS Church leadership in the videos included [[marijuana]], [[Islam]], the [[subprime mortgage crisis]], and a debate over the [[sexual orientation]] of [[Chelsea Manning]].<ref name=conferenceweekend /><ref name=mattcanham>{{citation|url=http://www.sltrib.com/lifestyle/faith/4423214-155/leaked-videos-show-mormon-apostles-discussing|first=Matt|last=Canham|title=Leaked videos show Mormon apostles discussing political influence, gay marriage, marijuana and more|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name=brieflook>{{citation|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/lds/4424105-155/a-brief-look-at-whats-in|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|title=A brief look at what’s in leaked Mormon videos|first1=Matt|last1=Canham|first2=David|last2=Noyce|first3=Benjamin|last3=Wood|first4=Peggy Fletcher|last4=Stack|date=October 2, 2016|accessdate=December 21, 2016}}</ref> LDS Church spokesman Eric Hawkins provided an official response, which stated: "In these committee meetings, presentations are routinely received from various religious, political and subject matter experts on various topics. The purpose is to understand issues that may face the Church, and is in pursuit of the obligation Church leaders feel to be informed on and have open discussion about current issues. This is an informational forum, not a decision-making body."<ref name=conferenceweekend /><ref name=seeitnow /><ref name=aldovazquez /> Hawkins pointed out the videos were from a timeframe of 2007 through 2012.<ref name=conferenceweekend /><ref name=seeitnow /><ref name=aldovazquez>{{citation|url=http://www.good4utah.com/news/local-news/videos-of-private-meetings-between-lds-leaders-leaked-online/590861820|work=[[KTVX]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 2, 2016|title=Videos of private meetings between LDS leaders leaked online|first=Aldo|last=Vazquez}}</ref>
In total the 15 videos were published to YouTube on the last day of the October 2016 LDS [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]].<ref name=mattcanham /><ref name=conferenceweekend>{{citation|work=[[KSTU]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 13, 2016|author=Fox 13 News|title=Videos of high-ranking LDS leaders discussing social issues anonymously released on conference weekend|url=http://fox13now.com/2016/10/02/videos-of-high-ranking-lds-leaders-discussing-social-issues-anonymously-released-on-conference-weekend/}}</ref><ref name=seeitnow>{{citation|accessdate=December 21, 2016|title=See it now: Mormon Leaks shares video of closed-door briefings of LDS Church leaders|date=October 2, 2016|url=http://gephardtdaily.com/local/mormon-leaks-videos/|work=Gephardt Daily}}</ref> Most of the videos were from closed session events only attended by high-level LDS Church leadership.<ref name=seeitnow /> The majority of them depicted lectures given to the [[Quorum of the Twelve]], the second-highest ranking leadership group within the LDS Church.<ref name=mattcanham /> [[Mike Leavitt]], former governor of Utah, appeared in a video filmed in 2012 and gave a presentation on [[State Religious Freedom Restoration Acts]].<ref name=mattcanham /> [[Gordon H. Smith]], former U.S. senator from Oregon, was shown in another video talking to the LDS Church leadership.<ref name=jeffmapes /><ref name=wweek>{{citation|url=http://www.wweek.com/news/2016/10/03/mormon-leaks-video-features-former-u-s-sen-gordon-smith-r-ore/|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 3, 2016|first=Nigel|last=Jaquiss|title=Mormon Leaks Video Features Former U.S. Sen. Gordon Smith (R-Ore.)|work=[[Willamette Week]]}}</ref> Smith lectured the LDS Church leaders about the "inestimable power" yielded from being able to contact U.S. Senators whenever necessary for assistance.<ref name=jeffmapes>{{citation|first=Jeff|last=Mapes|work=[[KUOW-FM]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 3, 2016|url=http://kuow.org/post/mormon-leaks-show-former-oregon-senator-who-did-favors-church|title='Mormon Leaks' Show Former Oregon Senator Who Did Favors For Church}}</ref> The lectures given to LDS Church leadership in this fashion were businesslike, with [[statistics]] and [[Microsoft PowerPoint]] presentations.<ref name=marybarker>{{citation|url=http://religiondispatches.org/mormon-leaks-boring-meetings-with-interesting-implications/|accessdate=December 21, 2016|work=[[Religion Dispatches]]|title=Mormon Leaks: Boring Meetings with Interesting Implications|date=November 1, 2016}}</ref>
McKnight suddenly found himself the point-person on the Internet for those wishing to maintain anonymity and yet simultaneously publicize secret documents from the LDS Church.<ref name=tareqhaddad>{{citation|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/disillusioned-ex-church-member-starts-mormon-wikileaks-shed-light-secretive-organisation-1597492|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=December 21, 2016|work=[[International Business Times]]|title=Disillusioned ex-church member starts 'Mormon Wikileaks' to shed light on secretive organisation|first=Tareq|last=Haddad}}</ref> After the videos engendered debate and attention from Mormons and the wider Internet community, McKnight was asked to add more videos from people who messaged him on [[Reddit]].<ref name=valkenburg /><ref name=leakedvideos /> After another anonymous user on Reddit asked him, he publicized documents from the LDS Church detailing a rules modification about homosexual partners.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> Reddit users asked him for a more secure means of submitting documents about the LDS Church.<ref name=bixenspan />
===Transition to dedicated website=== {{multiple image | width = 150 | image1 = Tor-logo-2011-flat.svg | alt1 = Tor | image2 = SecureDrop logo.svg | alt2 = SecureDrop | footer =MormonLeaks uses [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor privacy browser]] and [[secure communication]] [[SecureDrop]] to protect confidentiality.<ref name=alexjohnson /><ref name=notapproval /> }} McKnight decided to found MormonLeaks so whistleblowers could protect their [[anonymity]].<ref name=valkenburg /> Since his increased attention from the October videos and the November policy change leaks, McKnight has been contacted by 25 sources inside and outside of the LDS Church with potential material to release.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> McKnight and his team spent six months planning creation of the organization.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> He estimated approximately a potential for between hundreds to thousands of additional invididuals who may wish to leak information through the site.<ref name=notapproval /> The organization has no affiliation with [[Fred Karger#LDS Church|Fred Karger]] or his website [http://mormontips.com/ MormonTips.com], which also publicizes confidential documents from the LDS Church.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> MormonLeaks takes steps to protect [[confidentiality]] of their sources, including erasing all IP addresses from submissions and removing watermarks from submitted materials.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> The site asks users who wish to submit secret documents to use the [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor privacy browser]] to protect themselves.<ref name=alexjohnson /> Users then send the documents to MormonLeaks via [[SecureDrop]].<ref name=notapproval>{{citation|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|url=http://gephardtdaily.com/local/mormonwikileaker-seeks-lds-church-transparency-not-approval/|work=Gephardt Daily|title=MormonWikiLeaker seeks LDS Church ‘transparency,’ not approval}}</ref> [[Encryption]] methods are further incorporated to mask the identity of the whistleblowers.<ref name=tareqhaddad /> The motivation behind the organization is to increase transparency of LDS Church leadership.<ref name=sharesecret>{{citation|url=http://www.kivitv.com/news/former-lds-member-starts-mormon-wikileaks-to-share-secret-church-documents|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|title=Former LDS member starts Mormon Wikileaks to share secret church documents|work=[[KIVI-TV]]}}</ref><ref name=sirinkale>{{citation|first=Sirin|last=Kale|accessdate=December 21, 2016|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|url=https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/the-ex-mormon-exposing-the-lds-church-with-a-whistle-blowing-website|title=The Ex-Mormon Exposing the LDS Church With a Whistle-Blowing Website|date=December 21, 2016}}</ref>
MormonLeaks launched on December 19, 2016.<ref name=valkenburg>{{citation|url=http://gephardtdaily.com/religion/mormon-wikileaks-twitter-page-going-online-monday/|accessdate=December 20, 2016|title=Developing: Mormon WikiLeaks website, Twitter page going online Monday|first=Nancy |last=Van Valkenburg |date=December 15, 2016|work=Gephardt Daily}}</ref><ref name=exmormoncreates>{{citation|accessdate=December 20, 2016|url=http://kutv.com/news/local/ex-mormon-creates-mormonwikileaks-website-set-to-launch-on-monday|title=Ex-Mormon creates MormonWikiLeaks website, set to launch on Monday|first= Cimaron |last=Neugebauer|date= December 18, 2016|work=[[KUTV]]}}</ref><ref name=bixenspan>{{citation|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/former-lds-member-starts-mormonwikileaks-for-church-documents/|work=[[Mediaite]]|publisher=[[Dan Abrams|Abrams Media]]|accessdate=December 20, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|title=Former LDS Member Starts MormonWikiLeaks for Church Documents|first=David |last=Bixenspan }}</ref> The organization was started with a website and accompanying [[Twitter]] page.<ref name=valkenburg /> The MormonLeaks team works to verify documents before posting them live.<ref name=newwebsiteplans /><ref name=exmormoncreates /> This fact-checking team includes five volunteers and an attorney.<ref name=mandyvelez /> MormonLeaks does not take funding through advertising.<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> Funds to start MormonLeaks itself were initially raised through donations from [[GoFundMe]].<ref name=exmormoncreates /><ref name=mandyvelez /> The hope of its founder was that MormonLeaks would demonstrate the LDS Church's profitable nature as a business as opposed to its assertion of religious status.<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> The founder said it was highly unlikely the LDS Church would voluntarily publicize more of its innermost proceedings, saying it "will never be voluntarily transparent, they have nothing to gain from it".<ref name=exmormoncreates /> The site's intention was to avoid publishing specific lists of names of membership, and instead focus on economic information and internal organization policies and procedures.<ref name=witham /><ref name=sirinkale /> The site intended to limit disclosure of actual people's names to high-ranking officials including the [[Quorum of the Twelve]] and the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]].<ref name=witham /><ref name=mattmcdonald>{{citation|accessdate=December 20, 2016|first=Matt|last=McDonald|work=[[KSTU]]|title=‘MormonWikileaks’ website launched, seeking transparency in LDS Church|date=December 20, 2016}}</ref>
The organization's first leaks appeared on December 19, 2016, in the form of LDS Church documents from 2010.<ref name=mandyvelez /><ref name=alexjohnson>{{citation|work=[[NBC News]]|date=December 20, 2016|accessdate=December 21, 2016|first=Alex|last=Johnson|title=A 'Wikileaks' for Secret Church Documents Launches for Concerned Mormons|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/wikileaks-secret-church-documents-launches-concerned-mormons-n698496}}</ref> It published four files onto its account on Facebook as of December 20, 2016.<ref name=witham>{{citation|url=https://www.stgeorgeutah.com/news/archive/2016/12/20/jcw-mormon-wiki-leaks-launched|work=St George News|location=[[St. George, Utah]]|title=Former Mormon launches MormonWikiLeaks website seeking church transparency|first= Joseph |last=Witham|date=December 20, 2016|accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref> The first documents publicized by MormonLeaks included memos about legal procedures, a letter to the temple department's executive director regarding unsanctioned materials on the Internet, and an [[organizational chart]] for the [[intellectual property]] division of the LDS Church.<ref name=mattmcdonald /> MormonLeaks asserts to have been offered documents from two separate individuals who were employees of the LDS Church concerning [[tithing (Latter Day Saints)|tithing]] information of famous Mormons, including American football quarterback [[Steve Young]].<ref name=mattmcdonald />
After MormonLeaks had posted a handful a number of LDS Church documents for four months, the Church sent a [[cease-and-desist letter]] alleging [[copyright infringement]] with regard to a leaked Church leadership [[Microsoft PowerPoint|PowerPoint]] [[slide show|presentation]] published by MormonLeaks in February 2017. The PowerPoint discussed societal pressures that the Church felt had led some LDS members to apostasy, which included [[pornography]], the issues agitated for by [[Ordain Women]], and questions regarding [[Mormon history]] such as those promoted in books by lawyer / [[Fundamentalist Mormon]] [[Denver C. Snuffer Jr.|Denver Snuffer]] or in online postings by psychologist [[social critic]] [[John Dehlin]]. MormonLeaks pulled the offending document for a short while, until its attorney, [[Marc Randazza]], sent the LDS Church a letter which said, "At this point, my client is willing to let bygones be bygones. If your client is willing to step back from the brink, and to cease efforts to censor this material, my client is willing to refrain from bringing a claim [of abusing copyright law]."<ref name=mormonleaksreposts>{{citation|access-date=June 16, 2017|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/lds/5056058-155/mormonleaks-reposts-lds-church-apostasy-presentation|title=MormonLeaks reposts LDS Church apostasy presentation, rebuffs faith’s copyright violation claim|first=Bob|last=Mims|date=March 14, 2017}}</ref><ref name=enemieslist>{{citation|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2017/03/17/mormonleaks-website-squares-off-with-mormon-church-posts-leaked-enemies-list/|title=MormonLeaks website squares off with Mormon Church, posts leaked ‘Enemies List’|access-date=June 16, 2017|date=March 17, 2017|first= Michael Alison |last=Chandler}} </ref>
==Reception== [[WikiLeaks]] was aware of the foundation under the site's original name of MormonWikiLeaks, and sent them a message on Twitter asking them to change their name.<ref name=mandyvelez /> The founder stated he would retain the name as MormonWikiLeaks, and said a trademark application was pending.<ref name=mandyvelez />
[[University of Tampa]] professor Ryan Cragun said academics were excited to discover more information about the economics behind the LDS Church, as members tithe 10 percent of their earnings and there was not much in the way of transparent documents available to research their holdings and finances.<ref name=chandler /><ref name=":0" /> Cragun said it was unlikely active members of the LDS Church would end up viewing the leaked documents because they were "highly insulated".<ref name=chandler /><ref name=":0" /> However, he notes documents would have a greater impact on someone who is considering leaving the LDS Church: "For someone in the middle of a faith transition, such information is more fuel for the fire."<ref name=chandler /><ref name=":0" />
[[Editor-in-chief]] of ''The Nonprofit Quarterly'', Ruth McCambridge, wrote that the appearance of MormonLeaks was reflective of an increasing trend by individuals to use technology to force nonprofit organizations to be transparent and accountable to the public.<ref name=npq>{{citation|issn=1934-6050|oclc=46351191|publisher=Nonprofit Information Networking Association|location=[[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]|date=December 21, 2016|journal=The Nonprofit Quarterly|first=Ruth|last=McCambridge|accessdate=December 22, 2016|url=https://nonprofitquarterly.org/2016/12/21/forcing-nonprofit-transparency-mormon-church-ends-wikileaks/|archivedate=December 22, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222045913/https://nonprofitquarterly.org/2016/12/21/forcing-nonprofit-transparency-mormon-church-ends-wikileaks/|title=Forcing Nonprofit Transparency: Mormon Church Ends Up with Its Own Wikileaks}}</ref> MormonLeaks has an attorney on staff, which McCambridge notes may be beneficial given the prior litigation history where the LDS Church made a copyright infringement assertion against WikiLeaks for publishing the church's ''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook of Instructions]]''.<ref name=npq />
Mormon scholar and columnist [[Jana Riess]] was critical of the organization's tactics, stating: "I am very concerned about privacy in our culture more generally. People in the workplace have the right to expect that intraoffice communication and their emails will stay private."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> She called MormonLeaks "disturbing" and said: "It is not good news for any of us."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> On a positive note, Riess said it could motivate the upper LDS Church leadership to increase its transparency.<ref name=newwebsiteplans />
Utah attorney and Mormon blogger Steve Evans called MormonLeaks "a rebranding exercise of McKnight's existing practice of posting various confidential items."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> Evans said MormonLeaks had "an added layer of cybersecurity, which won't necessarily protect the leakers, depending on their methods of obtaining the various stolen documents, videos, etc."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> Evans was critical of McKnight's encouragement to those who choose to leak information to MormonLeaks: "the leakers are likely either church employees or consultants working for the church. In either of those situations, it's very likely that the leakers are violating their nondisclosure and confidentiality agreements with the church. McKnight is now publicly encouraging people to violate these agreements."<ref name=newwebsiteplans />

The '''Mugar family''' of [[Greater Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], is a prominent [[Armenian-American]] family in [[New England]] business and in philanthropy, both in the [[United States]] and in [[Armenia]]. The best known member of the family is [[Stephen P. Mugar]], (1901-1982), who founded the [[Star Market]] chain of super markets on which the family fortune was based. In its May, 2004, issue, [[Boston Magazine]] ranked the Mugar family sixth in its list of the 50 most influential Boston families.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120203221013/http://www.bostonmagazine.com/articles/the_fifty_families_part_1 "The Fifty Families (Part 1)"], ''Boston Magazine'', November 2006 (archived 2012)</ref>
==Family origin== The first family members to arrive in Boston were brothers, Charles and Martin Mugar (shortened from ''Mugardichian''), who came from [[Kharpert]], [[Ottoman Empire]], in 1904. They were joined in 1906 by their brothers, Arthur, Gregory and Sarkis Mugar, along with Sarkis Mugar's wife and three children, one of whom was Stephen P. Mugar.<ref>[http://www.arzo.com/arzo2/MIRROR_SPECTATOR%20February%2012,%201999.htm MIRROR_SPECTATOR February 12, 1999.htm<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Prominent family members== *[[Stephen P. Mugar]], (1901-1982) founder of the [[Star Market]] chain *[[John M. Mugar]], (1914-2007), son of Martin, President and Chairman of the Star Market chain. *[[David G. Mugar]], Stephen's son, also became a Star Market executive and is now a prominent businessman and philanthropist in his own right. *[[Carolyn Mugar]] Stephen's daughter, activist, is founder of the [[Armenia Tree Project]], executive director of [[Farm Aid]] and is the president of the [[Armenian Assembly of America]].
==Philanthropies== The major objects of Mugar family philanthropic giving have been: *Greater Boston educational institutions, especially the so-called "subway" or "commuter" colleges and universities, because they were the first to welcome young Armenian-Americans and others with limited resources and social standing and because they lacked the vast endowments of schools such as [[Harvard]]. *Hospitals, in particular [[Cape Cod Hospital]], and *Armenian causes in the United States and overseas in Armenia and Lebanon.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2016}} The '''National Digital Newspaper Program''' is a joint project between the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] and the [[Library of Congress]] to create and maintain a publicly available, online digital archive of historically significant newspapers published in the United States between 1836 and 1922. Additionally, the program will make available bibliographic records and holdings information for some 140,000 newspaper titles from the 17th century to the present. Further, it will include scope notes and encyclopedia-style entries discussing the historical significance of specific newspapers. Added content will also include contextually relevant historical information. "One organization within each U.S. state or territory will receive an award to collaborate with relevant state partners in this effort."<ref>[http://www.neh.gov/grants/guidelines/ndnp.html National Digital Newspaper Program<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In March 2007 more than 226,000 pages of newspapers from California, Florida, Kentucky, New York, Utah, Virginia and the District of Columbia published between 1900 and 1910 were put online at a fully searchable site called "[[Chronicling America]]." [https://www.loc.gov/chroniclingamerica/] As of December 2007, the total number of pages is about 413,000. This further expanded to be 1 million pages in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2009/09-123.html|title=Library of Congress, National Endowment for the Humanities Celebrate Millionth Page in Chronicling America Program|date=June 16, 2009 |publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=2009-07-24}}</ref> Funding through the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] is carried out through their "We The People" initiative.
== Purpose == This project dovetails with the [[United States Newspaper Program]] which was a massive project to microfilm newspaper collections. The initiators of that earlier project asserted that the intellectual content of newspapers serves an important role for researchers as it is for all intents and purposes the first draft of history. Newspapers also provide unique access to "diverse geographic viewpoints at the community level."<ref>[http://mlcnet.org/objects/rte/mediaupload/File/eventsdocs/events/05newspapers/05Sweeney-2_files/frame.htm The U.S. Newspaper Program – Scope, Achievement, and Progress<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Problematically, since the middle of the 19th century this "first draft" has been recorded on poor quality [[newsprint]] which is decaying rapidly. This digitization project's purpose is to continue preserving newspaper and newspaper collections while addressing the inadequacies of the prior program. Through digitization, it is more likely that images will be copied with fidelity and that the records will be more richly searchable. This latter point is huge as newspapers traditionally posed a research challenge due to density of text and inadequate cataloging of content.
== History == On March 31, 2004, [[Bruce Cole]], the directory of the NEH, and [[James H. Billington|James Billington]], the Librarian of Congress, signed an agreement creating the National Digital Newspaper Program. The NDNP follows in the footsteps of the successful [[United States Newspaper Program]], a several-decade effort to catalog and microfilm the bulk of America's historic newspapers. The program is broken down into two phases. Each successive phase will both increase the scope of the program and refine the requirements for data collection.
=== Phase 1 === In July 2004 the award guidelines were issued. Applications were due in October and awardees were announced the following March. The first phase took newspapers from a small subset of the states, limited to 1900 through 1910. After using this phase to improve technical requirements and specifications, the program was opened to other awardees in [[#Phase 2|Phase 2]].
The awardees for Phase 1 are: * [[University of California, Riverside]] * [[University of Florida Digital Collections|University of Florida Libraries]], Gainesville * [[University of Kentucky#Libraries|University of Kentucky Libraries]], Lexington * [[New York Public Library]], New York City * University of Utah, Salt Lake City [http://www.lib.utah.edu/digital/unews/] * Library of Virginia, Richmond
The General-access Phase 1 website prototype was implemented in March 2007 and that May it was announced that phase 1 was completed.
=== Phase 2 === Phase 2 of NDNP expanded grants to an additional group of institutions. Awards granted in 2007 and 2008 included the following institutions:
* [[Arizona State Library, Archives and Records Management]] * [[University of Hawaii]] * [[Minnesota Historical Society]] * [[University of Nebraska, Lincoln]] * [[University of North Texas]] * [[Ohio Historical Society]], Columbus * [[Pennsylvania State University]] * [[State Historical Society of Missouri]] * [[Washington State Library]]
== Program Technology == Participants must follow the technical guidelines laid out in a 64-page PDF.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/ndnp/pdf/NDNP_200709TechNotes.pdf Ndnp: Technical Notes On Formats For Digital Reproductions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The technology for the NDNP digital repository is being built using largely [[Open-source software|open source]] software, including: * [[Fedora (software)|Fedora]] * [[Apache Cocoon]] * [[Gentoo Linux]] * [[Apache Lucene]] Digital objects are stored in .TIFF 6.0, .JPEG 2000, and .PDF formats. Metadata is provided in the METS/MODS version of XML and XML provides the basis for larger hierarchical structures as well.
== Alternatives == The scanning efforts of the government entity has been dwarfed by the private efforts [[newspapers.com]] and [[newspaperarchive.com]] which as of March 2018 claim to each have scanned more than 350 million pages. Publishers, libraries and historical organizations find the private sector faster, less complicated and cheaper than the National Digital Newspaper Program.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} Both private organizations charge readers to read, but do not charge publishers to scan items.<ref>http://reason.com/blog/2014/05/18/a-retiree-digitizes-27-million-old-newsp</ref>
==See also== *[[United States Newspaper Program]]

{{italic title}} '''''Pari passu''''' is a [[Latin]] phrase that literally means "with an equal step" or "on equal footing". It is sometimes translated as "ranking equally",<ref name="Harriman">{{cite book | title=Harriman's Financial Dictionary: Over 2,600 Essential Financial Terms | author=Briscoe, Simon | year=2007 | pages=348 | author2=Fuller, Jane | quote=Ranking equally, meaning literally 'with equal step'. }}</ref> "hand-in-hand", "with equal force", or "moving together", and by extension, "fairly", "without partiality".<ref>{{cite web|title=Pari passu|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/pari-passu.html|website=Business Dictionary}}</ref>
==Etymology== :* ''[[Wiktionary:par#Inflection_2|pari]]'' is the [[ablative]] [[Singular number|singular]] [[masculine]] (since it must grammatically agree with ''passu'') of the [[adjective]] ''par'', "equal". If it were [[nominative]], "an equal step" it would be ''par passus''. :* ''[[Wiktionary:passus#Inflection|passu]]'' is the [[ablative]] of the Latin noun ''passus'', "step".
This term is commonly used in law. ''[[Black's Law Dictionary]]'' (8th ed., 2004) defines ''pari passu'' as "proportionally; at an equal pace; without preference".
==Usage== ===In inheritance=== In inheritance, an ''in pari passu'' (''[[per capita]]'') distribution can be distinguished from a ''[[per stirpes]]'' (by family branch) distribution.<ref name="per stirpes">{{cite web|title=Black's Law Dictionary |url=http://thelawdictionary.org/per-stirpes/ |work=2nd Edition|publisher=West Publishing|accessdate=10 December 2012|author=Henry Campbell Black}}</ref>
For example, suppose a [[testator]] had two children A and B. A has two children, and B has three. The testator leaves his entire estate to his grandchildren in equal shares ''in pari passu'', each grandchild would inherit one fifth of the estate. If the testator left his entire estate to his grandchildren ''per stirpes'' (by family branch), the children of A would share one half of the estate equally between the two of them, and the children of B would share one half of the estate equally amongst the three of them.
The problem with a per capita ''in pari passu'' distribution in the example given is as follows. Assume A dies before B. On A's death a distribution could not be made to his or her children: they would have to await the death of B – on the assumption that B could have additional children, and thereby consequently all grandchildren (of both A and B) would be entitled to less than one fifth each.
===In lending, bankruptcy and default=== This term is also often used in the [[lending]] area and in [[bankruptcy]] proceedings, where [[creditors]] are said to be paid ''pari passu'', or each creditor is paid ''[[pro rata]]'' in accordance with the amount of his claim. Here its meaning is "equally and without preference". There have been cases where decisions were based on different interpretations of the term.<ref>Devi Sookun Stop [[Vulture fund|Vulture Fund]] Lawsuits: A Handbook 2010 p34 2010 "The case succeeded because the court departed from the traditional meaning of the term pari passu. This section looks first at the original case of Elliott Associates v Republic of Peru."</ref><ref>Lloyd's maritime and commercial law quarterly 1983 "Obviously Lord Scott, in leaving out the preferential creditors, does not use the term pari passu in its multi-layered sense. Instead, his Lordship was referring to pari passu in its orthodox meaning."</ref>
In the [[European Union]], as the result of the [[Greek government-debt crisis]], a retroactive [[Collective action clause]] passed by the Greek government with the support of the [[European Central Bank|ECB]] and [[IMF]], enabled the debtor (who also controlled the courts) to impose a 70% loss on the creditors, more than 75% of whom had voted in favour of the cut. In this case, ''pari passu'' means that all private-sector investors are equally treated.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stevis|first1=Matina|last2=Burne|first2=Katy|title=Greek Legal Maneuvers Raise Fears of Euro-Zone Debt Fallout|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/eurocrisis/2012/02/23/greek-legal-maneuvers-raise-fears-of-euro-zone-debt-fallout/|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Statute of Bankrupts Act 1542]], introducing the ''pari passu'' principle for creditors of insolvent persons. ''Pari passu'' means treat at par from the previous issue. *[[Seniority (finance)]] *[[List of Latin phrases (P-R)|List of Latin Phrases]] *[[Collective action clause]] *[[Rights upon future offers]]
==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|2}}
===Further reading=== *[http://www.law.georgetown.edu/international/documents/pam.pdf law.georgetown.edu the ''pari passu'' clause in sovereign debt instruments] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040812111212/http://home.pacific.net.sg/~chanpal/article12.htm An analysis of Section 334 of the Companies Act and its effect on proceedings for the enforcement of Judgments - Section 334 and the pari passu principle]

'''Proteolix, Inc.''', was a private [[biotechnology]] company with headquarters in [[South San Francisco]], [[California]]. Proteolix was founded in 2003 based on technology developed by co-founders [[Craig M. Crews|Dr. Craig Crews]] (Yale University) and Dr. Raymond J. Deshaies (California Institute of Technology). Drs. Susan Molineaux and Phil Whitcome (deceased) joined Drs. Crews and Deshaies as co-founders. Proteolix was launched based on an $18.2 million A round comprising investments by Latterell Venture Partners, US Venture Partners, Advanced Technology Ventures, and The Vertical Group. Proteolix focused primarily on the [[proteasome]] as a therapeutic target. Its lead product candidate, [[carfilzomib]] (PR-171), is a [[tetrapeptide]] [[epoxyketone]]. At the time of its sale (see below), the company had two earlier-stage programs, an orally-bioavailable proteasome inhibitor for oncology (PR-047), and an agent preferentially targeting the immuno form of the proteasome (PR-957), with potential utility in areas such as rheumatoid arthritis. At the time of sale, Carfilzomib's route of administration was [[intravenous]], and the company was exploring its potential utility in [[multiple myeloma]], [[Non-Hodgkin lymphoma]] (NHL) and other cancers.
Proteolix was acquired by [[Onyx Pharmaceuticals]] in 2009 for $810 million (nominal value). Onyx renamed PR-047 to "[https://web.archive.org/web/20110523065128/http://www.onyx-pharm.com/clinical-development/onx-091 ONX 0912]" and PR-957 to "[https://web.archive.org/web/20110523065128/http://www.onyx-pharm.com/clinical-development/onx-091 ONX 0914]".
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040129224420/http://www.proteolix.com/ Proteolix's corporate website]

'''School-Based Family Counseling''' (SBFC) is an integrated approach to [[mental health]] intervention that focuses on both [[school]] and [[family]] in order to help children overcome personal problems and succeed at school.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carter|first1=M.|last2=Evans|first2=W.|title=Urban school-based family counseling: Role definition, practice applications, and training implications|journal=[[Journal of Counseling and Development]]|date=1997|volume=75|issue=5|pages=366–374}}</ref> SBFC is practiced by a wide variety of mental health professionals, including: [[psychologists]], [[social workers]], [[school counselors]], [[psychiatrists]], and [[marriage and family therapists]], as well as [[special education]] teachers.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Casey|first1=J.|last2=Buchan|first2=G.|title=Family approaches to school psychology: Brief strategic family intervention|journal=[[School Psychology International]]|date=1991|volume=12|issue=4|pages=349–353|doi=10.1177/0143034391124006}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dicocco|first1=B.|last2=Chalfin|first2=S.|last3=Olson|first3=J.|title=Systemic family therapy goes to school|journal=[[Social Work in Education]]|date=1987|volume=9|issue=4|pages=209–221}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Davis|first1=K.|title=Structural-strategic family counseling: a case study in elementary school counseling|journal=[[Professional School Counseling]]|date=2001|volume=4|issue=3|pages=180–186}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pittman|first1=F.|last2=Langsley|first2=D.|last3=Deyoung|first3=C.|title=Work and school phobias: A family approach to treatment|journal=[[American Journal of Psychiatry]]|date=1968|volume=124|issue=11|pages=1535–1541|doi=10.1176/ajp.124.11.1535}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rotter|first1=J.|last2=Boveja|first2=M.|title=Family therapists and school Education]]|date=1987|volume=14|issue=3|pages=119–121|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8578.1987.tb00305.x}}</ref> What they all share in common is the belief that children who are struggling in [[school]] can be best helped by interventions that link [[family]] and [[school]].<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Fine|editor1-first=M.|editor2-last=Carlson|editor2-first=C.|title=Family-school intervention: A systems perspective.|date=1965|publisher=[[Allyn & Bacon]]|location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Miller|editor1-first=L.|title=Integrating school and family counseling: Practical therapy.|date=2000|publisher=The Guilford Press|location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sherman|first1=R.|last2=Shumsky|first2=A.|last3=Roundtree|first3=Y.|title=Enlarging the therapeutic systems theory and family therapy in the resolution of school problems.|date=1997|publisher=Charles C. Thomas|location=New York}}</ref> SBFC is typically practiced at the school site, but may be based in a community [[mental health]] agency that works in close collaboration with schools.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Nicoll|first1=W.|editor1-last=Walsh|editor1-first=W.|editor2-last=Williams|editor2-first=G.|title=Schools and family therapy: Using systems theory and family therapy in the resolution of school problems.|date=1997|publisher=Charles C. Thomas|location=Springfield, Ill.|chapter=Ch. 9 A family counseling and consultation model for school counselors.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Klein|first1=E.|title=Forging partnerships to meet family needs|journal=School Administrator|date=2004|volume=61|issue=7|pages=40–45}}</ref>
==The Need for SBFC==
Family problems, such as marital discord, [[divorce]], financial difficulties, [[child abuse]] and neglect, life-threatening illness, sibling in a [[gang]], and poor [[parenting skills]] are associated with a wide variety of children's problems, e.g. [[Juvenile delinquency|delinquency]], [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[suicide]] attempts, and [[substance abuse]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Henderson|first1=A.|last2=Sager|first2=T.|last3=Horne|first3=A.|title=Mothers and sons: A look at the relationship between child behavior problems, marital satisfaction, maternal depression, and family cohesion|journal=The Family Journal|date=2003|volume=11|issue=1|pages=33–41|doi=10.1177/1066480702238469}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Evans|first1=E.|last2=Hawton|first2=K.|last3=Rodham|first3=K.|title=In what ways are adolescents who engage in self-harm or experience thoughts of self-harm different in terms of help-seeking, communication and coping strategies?|journal=Journal of Adolescence|date=2005|volume=28|issue=4|pages=573–587|doi=10.1016/j.adolescence.2004.11.001}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goldstein|first1=S.|last2=Davis-Kean|first2=P.|last3=Eccles|first3=J.|title=Parents, peers and problem behavior: A longitudinal investigation of the impact of relationship perceptions and characteristics on the development of adolescent problem behavior|journal=Developmental Psychology|date=2005|volume=41|issue=2|pages=401–413|doi=10.1037/0012-1649.41.2.401|pmid=15769195}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Henry|first1=C.|last2=Robinson|first2=L.|last3=Wilson|first3=S.|title=Adolescent perceptions of their family system, parents' behavior, self-esteem, and family life|journal=Journal of Child and Adolescent Substance Abuse|date=2004|volume=13|issue=2|pages=29–59|doi=10.1300/j029v13n02_02}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hacker |first1=K.|last2=Suglia |first2=S. |last3=Fried Life-threatening Behavior|date=2006|volume=36|issue=2|pages=154–166 |doi=10.1521/suli.2006.36.2.154}}</ref> These family problems can have a negative effect on children's learning and school behavior.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Crespi|first1=T.|last2=Gustafson|first2=A.|last3=Borges|first3=S.|title=Group counseling in the schools: Considerations for child and family issues|journal=Journal of Applied and School Psychology|date=2006|volume=22|issue=1|pages=67–85|doi=10.1300/j370v22n01_04}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lagana|first1=M.|title=Protective factors for inner-city adolescents journal|last1=Ponsford|first1=K.|last2=Lapadat|first2=J.|title=Academically capable students who are failing in high school: Perceptions about achievement|journal=Canadian Journal of Counselling|date=2001|volume=35|issue=2|pages=137–156}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sun|first1=Y.|last2=Li|first2=Y.|title=Children's well-being during parents' marital disruption process: A pooled time-series analysis|journal=Journal of Marriage and Family|date=2002|volume=64|issue=2|pages=472–488|doi=10.1111/j.1741-3737.2002.00472.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Heard|first1=H.|title=Fathers, mothers, and family structure: Family trajectories, parent gender, and adolescent schooling|journal=Journal of Marriage and the Family|date=2007|volume=69|issue=2|pages=435–450|doi=10.1111/j.1741-3737.2007.00375.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Abdelnoor|first1=A.|last2=Hollins|first2=S.|title=The effect of childhood bereavement on secondary school performance|journal=Educational Psychology in Practice|date=2004|volume=20|issue=1|pages=43–54|doi=10.1080/0266736042000180401}}</ref> However, there is research showing that healthy families that cope effectively with their problems help children succeed at school.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lambert|first1=S.|last2=Cashwell|first2=C.|title=Preteens talking to parents: Perceived communication and school-based aggression|journal=The Family Journal|date=2004|volume=12|issue=2|pages=122–128|doi=10.1177/1066480703261953}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zimmer-Gembeck|first1=M.|last2=Locke|first2=E.|title=The socialization of adolescent coping behaviours: Relationships with families and teachers|journal=Journal of Adolescence|date=2007|volume=30|issue=1|pages=1–16|doi=10.1016/j.adolescence.2005.03.001|pmid=16837040}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Steward|first1=R.|last2=Jo|first2=H.|last3=Murray|first3=D.|last4=Fitzgerald|first4=W.|last5=Neil|first5=D.|last6=Fear|first6=F.|last7=Hill|first7=M.|title=Psychological adjustment and coping styles of urban African American high school students|journal=Journal of Multicultural Counseling and Adjustment|date=1998|volume=26|issue=2|pages=70–82|doi=10.1002/j.2161-1912.1998.tb00188.x}}</ref> Traditionally trained school counselors and school psychologists may lack the family counseling training necessary to help students who are experiencing problems at home.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wendt|first1=R.|last2=Zake|first2=J.|title=Family systems therapy and school psychology: Implications for training and practice|journal=Psychology in the Schools|date=1984|volume=21|issue=2|pages=204–210|doi=10.1002/1520-6807(198404)21:2<204::aid-pits2310210212>3.0.co;2-z}}</ref> If school personnel recommend that a parent seek counseling from a community agency for family problems, the parent and family may not go because of the [[Social stigma|stigma]] associated with therapy or because of restrictions imposed by [[managed care]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vogel|first1=D.|last2=Wade|first2=G.|last3=Hackler|first3=H.|title=Perceived public stigma and the willingness to seek counseling:The mediating roles of self-stigma and attitudes toward counseling|journal=[[Journal of Counseling Psychology]]|date=2007|volume=54|issue=1|pages=40–50|doi=10.1037/0022-0167.54.1.40}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Crespi|first1=T.|last2=Hughes|first2=T.|title=School-based mental health services for adolescents: School psychology in contemporary society|journal=[[Journal of Applied School Psychology]]|date=2004|volume=20|issue=1|pages=67–78|doi=10.1300/j370v20n01_05}}</ref> SBFC reduces the [[Social stigma|stigma]] associated with therapy by emphasizing that counseling for family members has an educational goal: helping the student to succeed at school. [[Parents]], [[Legal guardian|guardians]], and family members are approached as partners with the SBFC professional, all working together to promote school success.The SBFC professional is an [[advocate]] for the [[child]], the [[family]], and the [[school]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Soriano|first1=M.|last2=Hong|first2=G.|title=School-based family services: Administrative leadership for a caring model of effective education|journal=Journal for a Just and Caring Education|date=1997|volume=3|issue=2|pages=180–191}}</ref> Some of the problems SBFC approaches have been used to address are:[[bullying]] and [[cyber-bullying]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Murray-Harvey|first1=R.|last2=Slee|first2=P.|title=School and home relationships and their impact on school bullying|journal=School Psychology International|date=2010|volume=31|issue=3|pages=271–295|doi=10.1177/0143034310366206}}</ref> [[Depression (mood)|depression]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Woods|first1=B.|title=Kiwi ACE - an indicated preventive depression programme in schools.|date=2001|publisher=Ministry of Education, New Zealand.|location=New Zealand}}</ref> marital problems,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Migrant Family Resilience Project|title=Making strong couples programme|date=2012|publisher=University of Auckland|location=Auckland, New Zealand}}</ref> [[school violence]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Marcheti-Mercer|first1=M.|title=The value of using a school-based family counseling approach following an incident of school violence|journal=International Journal for School-Based Family Counseling|date=2008|volume=1}}</ref> [[grief]] and loss,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fitzgerald|first1=H.|title=Grief at school: Resource manual.|date=2000|publisher=American Hospice Foundation|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> [[Injury|trauma]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wasserstein|first1=S.|last2=La Greca|first2=A.|title=Hurricane Andrew: Parent conflict as a moderator of children's adjustment|journal=Hispanic Journal of Behavioural Sciences|date=1998|volume=20|issue=2|pages=212–224|doi=10.1177/07399863980202005}}</ref> life-threatening illness,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stanco|first1=C.|last2=Taub|first2=D.|title=A counseling group for children of cancer patients|journal=Journal for Specialists in Group Work|date=2002|volume=27|issue=1|pages=43–58}}</ref> school crises,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Morrison|first1=J.|last2=Russo|first2=C.|last3=Ilg|first3=T.|title=School-based crisis intervention: Its effectiveness and role in broader crisis intervention plans|journal=International Journal of Educational Reform|date=2006|volume=15|pages=331–343}}</ref> learning disorders,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shechtman|first1=Z.|last2=Gilat|first2=I.|title=The effectiveness of counseling groups in reducing stress of parents of children with learning disabilities|journal=Group Dynamics: Theory, Research, and Practice|date=2005|volume=9|issue=4|pages=275–286|doi=10.1037/1089-2699.9.4.275}}</ref> [[immigrant]] families,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Everts|first1=H.|title=Applying principles of school-based family counseling to preventive intervention with migrant and refugee families.|date=2007|publisher=Paper presented at the Fifth Oxford Symposium in SBFC|location=University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong}}</ref> [[suicide]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Talbott|first1=L.|last2=Bartlett|first2=M.|title=Youth suicide postvention: Support for survivors and recommendations for school Copper River Project" in Copper River District Alaskan schools;<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Morotti|first1=A.|title=The Copper River Project: Laying the foundation for school-based family counseling with schools.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Adams-Langley|first1=S.|title=Place2BE in the inner city: A school-based mental health service.|date=2012|publisher=Paper presented at the Oxford Symposium in School-Based Family Counseling|location=Brasenose College, Oxford University}}</ref>
==Origins== The earliest pioneer of SBFC was [[Alfred Adler]], the Austrian psychiatrist who developed 30 guidance clinics attached to schools in [[Vienna]] in the 1920s. Through these guidance clinics Adler and his colleagues counseled parents and teachers (often both together in large meetings where both groups were present) on how to help children overcome problems at home and school. This Adlerian home-school approach to counseling was strength-based with its emphasis on helping children develop Social Interest.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Adler|first1=A.|title=The education of children|date=1930|publisher=Gateway|location=Chicago, Ill.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Adler|first1=A.|title=A doctor remakes education|journal=Survey|date=1927|volume=58|pages=490–501}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ansbacher|first1=H.|last2=Ansbacher|first2=R.|title=The individual psychology of Alfred Adler.|date=1956|publisher=Harper Perennial|location=New York}}</ref>
==Later Developments== With the advent of [[World War II]], the Vienna guidance clinics closed. The psychiatrist [[Rudolf Dreikurs]], who worked with Adler, emigrated to the USA in the 1930s and popularized the Adlerian approach to home-school intervention through books like: Children the Challenge (for parents), Maintaining Sanity in the Classroom (for teachers), and Discipline Without Tears (for parents and teachers).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dreikurs|first1=R.|title=Children the challenge.|date=1958|publisher=Norton|location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dreikurs|first1=R.|title=Maintaining sanity in the classroom.|date=1968|publisher=Harper and Row|location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dreikurs|first1=R.|last2=Cassel|first2=P.|title=Discipline without tears.|date=1965|publisher=Harper and Row|location=New York}}</ref> In the USA, during the 1950s, 60's, and 70's the [[mental health professions]] developed somewhat independently of each other with the result that children having difficulty at school would typically be seen by a [[school counselor]] or [[school psychologist]]. Children having difficulty at home would typically be seen by a community-based [[mental health professional]]. Beginning in the 1970s the [[mental health]] literature begins to show an increasing emphasis on linking home and school interventions. By 2000 there existed a substantial literature on the integration of family and school counseling approaches.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gerrard|first1=B.|title=School-based family counseling: Overview, trends, and recommendations for future research|journal=International Journal for School-Based Family Counseling|date=2008|volume=1|pages=1–30}}</ref>
==Strengths of SBFC==
SBFC is a strength-based approach to counseling that emphasizes working with [[parents]] and [[Legal guardian|guardians]] as partners. It emphasizes integrating intervention (remedial) and [[Risk|prevention]] approaches at school and in the family. This emphasis on working collaboratively with parents and guardians in order to help their children succeed in school is appealing to families because of its educational focus. SBFC is a multiculturally sensitive counseling approach because it reduces the stigma associated with the [[mental health professions]]. This approach is practiced by many different [[mental health professionals]] and [[educators]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Soriano|first1=M.|last2=Hong|first2=G.|title=School-based family services: Administrative leadership for a caring model of effective education|journal=Journal for a Just and Caring Education|date=1997|volume=3|issue=2|pages=180–191}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carter|first1=M.|last2=Evans|first2=W.|title=Urban school-based family counseling: Role definition, practice applications, and training implications|journal=[[Journal of Counseling and Development]]|date=1997|volume=75|issue=5|pages=366–374}}</ref>
==Challenges for SBFC==
Most of the research supporting SBFC is descriptive and correlational. There is a need for rigorous [[randomized controlled trials]] of a variety of SBFC approaches.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gerrard|first1=B.|title=School-based family counseling: Overview, trends, and recommendations for future research|journal=[[International Journal for School-Based Family Counseling]]|date=2008|volume=1|issue=1–30}}</ref> Traditional [[mental health profession]] academic programs tend to emphasize interventions that focus on school intervention or family intervention, but not both. The development of SBFC programs requires both [[cross-disciplinary]] and [[cross-cultural]] thinking and a willingness to set aside mental health professional "turf" issues.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Soriano|first1=M.|last2=Hong|first2=G.|title=School-based family services: Administrative leadership for a caring model of effective education|journal=[[Journal for a Just and Caring Education]]|date=1997|volume=3|issue=2|pages=180–191}}</ref>

'''Sven Johan Gösta Barthen Hagströmer''' (born 30 November 1943) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] business executive, best known as the founder of [[Avanza Bank]]<ref>[https://www.avanza.se/aza/omavanza/pdf/cv/sven_hagstromer.pdf Avanza, about Sven Hagströmer]</ref> and investment company Creades.<ref>[http://www.creades.se/om-creades/ Creades, about Sven Hagströmer]</ref> He is also the initiator of the non-profit organizations AllBright<ref>[http://www.allbright.se/new-page-2/ AllBright, about Sven Hagströmer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317045831/http://www.allbright.se/new-page-2/ |date=2016-03-17 }}</ref> and Berättarministeriet.<ref>[http://berattarministeriet.se/om-oss/styrelse Berättarministeriet, about Sven Hagströmer]</ref>
==Education and early career== Sven Hagströmer studied economics at [[Stockholm University]]. He was a portfolio manager at Gränges AB from 1969 to 1973 and at Investor from 1973 to 1980. He started the firm Sven Hagströmer Fondkommission AB in 1981. It later turned into the commercial bank Hagströmer & Qviberg, publicly known as [[HQ Bank]]. HQ Bank was the principal owner of Investment AB Öresund, which was divided into two companies in 2012. Business partners Sven Hagströmer and Mats Qviberg went separate ways and Sven Hagströmer became the principal owner of the newly formed investment company Creades. Amongst a number of directorships, he is now Chairman of the Board of both Avanza Bank and Creades. Sven Hagströmer is a dedicated entrepreneur and was one of the venture capitalist "dragons" in the Swedish version of the television program [[Dragons' Den (Canadian TV series)|Dragons’ Den]] on [[Sveriges Television|SVT]].<ref>[http://www.driva-eget.se/nyheter/pengar/han-satsade-mest-i-draknastet "Satsade mest i Draknästet"] Driva-eget.se</ref>
==Political views== Sven Hagströmer is involved in various social projects, including Arbetsmäklarna at Tensta School where he helps young students get in touch with employers. He believes that Swedish companies are not doing enough to bring in people from other cultures.<ref>[http://www.va.se/nyheter/vagrar-sitta-med-armarna-i-kors-77127/ "Vägrar sitta med armarna i kors"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120711182414/http://www.va.se/nyheter/vagrar-sitta-med-armarna-i-kors-77127 |date=2012-07-11 }} Veckans Affärer</ref> Hagströmer is opposed to the euro and was one of the initiators to the political party Junilistan.<ref>[http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/pressreleases/foeraendring-i-junilistans-styrelse-109615 "Förändring i Junilistans styrelse"] Junilistan</ref><ref>[http://www.dn.se/nyheter/politik/junilistan-far-draghjalp-till-riksdagen-av-finansman/ "Junilistan får draghjälp till riksdagen av finansman" ] Dagens Nyheter</ref> He believes that the euro reduces the Riksbank's influence over monetary policy.<ref>[http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article10394197.ab "-Visst minskar EMU folkets inflytande"] Aftonbladet</ref> Sven Hagströmer is a relative of Raoul Wallenberg and he founded the Raoul Wallenberg Academy in 2012. He is a passionate book collector<ref>[http://www.fokus.se/2007/11/sven-hagstromer-finansman-och-slaktare/ "Sven Hagströmer - finansman och slaktare"] Fokus. Read 3 August 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.svt.se/2.108659/1.1495855/sven_hagstromer "Sven Hagströmer - styrelseordförande i Investment AB Öresund, Avanza och Ework samt styrelseledamot i Bilia"] SVT. Read 3 August 2010</ref> and founded the publishing agency Fri Tanke together with Christer Sturmark and Björn Ulvaeus in 2007. Sven Hagströmer is one of the initiators of Berättarministeriet, which runs writing workshops in areas with high unemployment rates. He is also committed to gender issues and is frequently seen in the public gender equality debate. In 2011 he founded the AllBright foundation that works in order to increase the number of women holding positions of power within the business sector.
