Scripps Company|accessdate=11 October 2012|date=11 October 2012}} ===F-35 alternative engine=== [[File:Sdd f136 006.jpg|thumb|GE/Rolls-Royce engine for F-35]] Rooney fought to remove spending for an alternate engine program (built by [[GE Aviation]] and [[Rolls-Royce plc]]) for the [[F-35 Joint Strike Fighter]]. [[The Pentagon]] had already taken the position that having a single contractor ([[Pratt & Whitney]]) will save money. "The Pentagon has said repeatedly that they do not want it and do not need it, and the American taxpayers certainly cannot afford it," Rooney said.{{cite news |url= http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/16/house-breaks-old-taboos-in-cutting-spree/ |title= House breaks old taboos in cutting spree |last= Dinan |first= Stephen |date= 16 February 2011 |newspaper= Washington Times |accessdate= 16 August 2012}} Rooney sponsored an amendment to the 2012 House spending bill to end funding for the extra engine of the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, which passed with support from freshman members of the [[Tea Party Caucus]].{{cite news |url= http://www.defensepolicy.org/2011/congressman-tom-rooney/congressman-tom-rooney-defund-the-jsf-alternate-engine |title= Defund the JSF Alternate Engine |last= Rooney |first= Tom |date= 21 February 2011 |newspaper= DefensePolicy.org |accessdate= 29 August 2012}}{{cite news|title=Tom Rooney (R-Fla.)|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/tom-rooney-r-fla/gIQADjiUAP_topic.html|work=WP Politics|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=29 August 2012|first=Greg|last=Sargent|date=24 July 2012}} In December 2011 GE abandoned self-funding to continue development of its alternate engine, finally ending the project. Rooney said that the decision by GE "will finally remove any risk that taxpayers may be saddled with the costs of sustaining an extra engine in the future."{{cite news |url= https://finance.yahoo.com/news/GE-Aviation-ends-F-35-fighter-apf-3630210224.html |title= GE Aviation ends F-35 fighter engine development |last= Sewell |first= Dan |date= 2 December 2011 |newspaper= Yahoo! Finance |accessdate= 29 August 2012}} ===Terrorism=== Rooney criticised [[Justin Amash]] in May 2012, accusing the Michigan Republican of wanting to "coddle foreign enemy combatants" because he proposed an amendment to the [[National Defense Authorization Act]] (NDAA) to stop the military from indefinitely detaining suspected terrorists who were caught in the United States. Amash and Congressman [[Adam Smith (politician)|Adam Smith]] said they worried about civil liberties and the constitutionality of allowing indefinite detention of U.S. residents suspected of being terrorists.{{cite news |url= http://politics.heraldtribune.com/2012/05/17/area-congressman-debates-how-to-treat-suspected-terrorists/ |title= Area congressman debates how to treat suspected terrorists |last= Wallace |first= Jeremy |date= 17 May 2012 |newspaper= Sarasota Herald-Tribune |accessdate= 30 August 2012 |quote=Rooney later took to the House floor to argue in support of another amendment he proposed that would force suspected foreign terrorists and enemy combatants to be tried by a military commission in Guantanamo Bay in Cuba instead of in U.S. courts.}} A Rooney press release said that "the Amash amendment sacrifices our national security in order to coddle foreign enemy combatants. Never in our nation's history have we granted enemy combatants who attack our homeland during a time of war the same rights and privileges of American citizens, but that's exactly what the Amash amendment would do."{{cite news |url= http://www.rollcall.com/news/tom_rooney_accuses_justin_amash_of_coddling_terrorists-214629-1.html |title= Tom Rooney Accuses Justin Amash of Coddling Terrorists |last= Stanton |first= John |date= 17 May 2012 |newspaper= Roll Call |accessdate= 16 August 2012 |quote=Rooney, a former military prosecutor, ripped into his colleague as the House prepared to debate Amash's bipartisan amendment to the defense reauthorization bill that would eliminate the authority of the military to indefinitely detain individuals suspected of being terrorists who were caught within the United States.}}{{cite web |url= http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3393 |title= Amash Amendment Rewards al Qaeda Attacks on U.S. Soil |date= 17 May 2012 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website |accessdate= 30 August 2012}} Rooney's press release was criticised in turn by a statement from [[Ron Paul]]'s [[Campaign for Liberty]] which accused Rooney of being "disgracefully dishonest."{{cite web |url= http://www.campaignforliberty.org/profile/7786/blog/2012/05/17/disgracefully-dishonest |title= Representative Rooney's Disgracefully Dishonest Release |date= 17 May 2012 |work= Blog |publisher= Campaign for Liberty |accessdate= 30 August 2012 |quote=...Congressmen like Tom Rooney would seek to turn the judicial system on its head.}} Finally, Rooney issued a statement of support for a competing amendment to the NDAA by congressmen [[Jeff Landry]], [[Louie Gohmert]] and [[Scott Rigell]]: "The Landry/Gohmert/Rigell amendment explicitly re-affirms and protects the constitutional rights of American citizens, and states clearly that no citizens' constitutional rights can be denied under the provisions of the defense bill... While it's critical that we protect the rights of American citizens, we should absolutely not exploit legitimate concerns in a misguided effort to extend our rights and privileges to foreign terrorists who attack our homeland." The Amash/Smith amendment was defeated and the Landry/Gohmert/Rigell amendment was adopted, both by large margins.{{cite news |url=https://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2012/05/republicans-ndaa-detention-terrorist |title= House GOP Kills Proposal to Block Indefinite Detention of US Citizens |last= Drum |first= Kevin |date= 18 May 2012 |newspaper= Mother Jones |accessdate= 30 August 2012 |quote=...when Republicans like Rooney say that Smith and Amash want to "coddle terrorists," they're not necessarily talking about some heavily armed Al Qaeda fighter in Kandahar. They're potentially talking about you.}}{{cite web |url= http://gohmert.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=296195 |title= Rep. Gohmert's Amendment to the NDAA Adopted |date= 18 May 2012 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Louie Gohmert Website |accessdate= 30 August 2012}} ===Muslim Brotherhood controversy=== On June 13, 2012, Rooney was one of five members of Congress (including [[Michele Bachmann]], [[Trent Franks]], [[Louie Gohmert]] and [[Lynn Westmoreland]]) to send letters to the Inspectors General{{cite web |url=http://bachmann.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=303218 |title=House Members Seek National Security Answers|date=13 June 2012 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congresswoman Michele Bachmann Website |accessdate=23 August 2012}} of the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the Department of Defense, the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Justice and the Department of State seeking investigations into what they claimed was the U.S. government's involvement with the [[Muslim Brotherhood]]. One of the letters in particular to Ambassador Harold W. Geisel, the Deputy [[Inspector General]] of the [[United States Department of State]], used the Department's Deputy [[Chief of Staff]], [[Huma Abedin]], as an example of the undue influence. The letter said that Abedin "has three family members–her late father, her mother and her brother–connected to Muslim Brotherhood operatives and/or organizations," referring to a study by the [[Center for Security Policy]].{{cite web |url=http://bachmann.house.gov/uploadedfiles/ig_letter_dept_of_state.pdf |title=Letter to the Deputy Inspector General |author= |date=13 June 2012 |format=PDF |publisher=Congress of the United States |accessdate=19 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719054658/http://bachmann.house.gov/uploadedfiles/ig_letter_dept_of_state.pdf |archivedate=19 July 2012 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Cordes|first=Nancy|title=Michele Bachmann refuses to back down on claims about Huma Abedin|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505267_162-57475483/michelle-bachmann-refuses-to-back-down-on-claims-about-huma-abedin/|accessdate=19 July 2012|newspaper=CBS This Morning|date=19 July 2012 |quote=Bachmann, from Minnesota, and the four other representatives sent letters to top intelligence and security officials last week warning that the Muslim Brotherhood, a global religious Islamic movement whose members have been linked to terrorist groups in the past, may have infiltrated the top levels of U.S. government.}}{{cite web |url=http://muslimbrotherhoodinamerica.com/key-findings/ |title=Key Findings |last=Gaffney |first=Frank |date= |work=The Muslim Brotherhood in America |publisher=Center for Security Policy |accessdate=11 August 2012 |quote=Notably, six Islamist-sympathizers have achieved positions within or advisory roles serving Team Obama: Special Envoy to the Organization of Islamic Cooperation Rashad Hussein; Deputy Chief of Staff to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton Huma Abedein; Presidential advisor Dalia Mogahed; FBI Citizens Academy graduate Kifah Mustafa; Homeland Security Advisory Committee Member Mohamed Elibiary and Homeland Security Countering Violent Extremism Working Group Member Mohamed Magid.}} Republican Senators [[John McCain]], [[Lindsey Graham]], and [[Scott Brown (politician)|Scott Brown]], as well as Bachmann's former campaign chief [[Ed Rollins]] defended Abedin against these allegations.{{cite news|last=Rollins|first=Edward|title=Bachmann's former campaign chief – shame on you, Michele |url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2012/07/18/bachmann-former-campaign-chief-shame-on-michele/|publisher=FoxNews|accessdate=24 July 2012|date=18 July 2012}}{{cite news|last=Terkel|first=Amanda|title=John McCain Slams Michele Bachmann's 'Unfounded' Attacks On Huma Abedin, Muslim-Americans|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/18/john-mccain-michele-bachmann-muslim_n_1683277.html|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=19 July 2012|date=18 July 2012}} Speaker of the House [[John Boehner]] told reporters: "I don't know Huma. But from everything that I do know of her, she has a sterling character, and I think accusations like this being thrown around are pretty dangerous."{{cite news|last=O'Keefe|first=Ed|title=John Boehner: Accusations against Huma Abedin 'pretty dangerous'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/2chambers/post/john-boehner-accusations-against-huma-abedin-pretty-dangerous/2012/07/19/gJQAeDT6vW_blog.html|accessdate=19 July 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=19 July 2012}} Congressman [[Mike Simpson]] condemned the letter as a revival of [[McCarthyism]], telling the ''[[Idaho Statesman]]'': "Unfortunately, it's not just Michele. The public says, 'There go those Republicans again.' It's a bad reflection on all Republicans. I can't believe the other four members she got to sign the letter with her. Amazing... That doesn't reflect the House Republican Caucus."{{cite web |url=http://voices.idahostatesman.com/2012/08/10/idahopolitics/idahos_rep_simpson_says_michele_bachmann_reviving_mccarthyism_ta |title=Idaho's Rep. Simpson says Michele Bachmann reviving McCarthyism 'outrageous,' tainting all Republicans |last=Popkey |first=Dan |date=10 August 2012 |work=Idaho Politics's Blog |publisher=Idaho Statesman |accessdate=11 August 2012 |quote=Seven-term GOP Rep. Mike Simpson said Friday that Rep. Michele Bachmann's claim that an extremist Islamic group has infiltrated the U.S. government is a revival of McCarthyism that must be condemned.}} An editorial in [[Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers]] also brought up the ghost of McCarthyism, explicitly pronouncing disappointment in Rooney.{{cite web |url=http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2012/aug/09/editorial-rooneys-involvement-in-islamist-scare/ |title=Rooney's involvement in Islamist scare-mongering out of character, disappointing |author=Editorial Board |date=9 August 2012 |work=TCPalm.com |publisher=Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |accessdate=11 August 2012 |quote=It's difficult to imagine U.S. Rep. Tom Rooney associating himself with the ranting of former presidential candidate Michele Bachmann, his House colleague.}} On the other hand, Newt Gingrich argued in favor of investigation into the Muslim Brotherhood, characterizing Rooney and the rest as the "National Security Five."{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0712/79104.html |title=In defense of Michele Bachmann, Muslim Brotherhood probes |last=Gingrich |first= |last2=Newt |date=29 July 2012 |work=Opinion Contributor |publisher=Politico |accessdate=11 August 2012 |quote=The underlying driving force behind this desperate desire to stop unpleasant questions is the elite's fear that an honest discussion of radical Islamism will spin out of control. They fear if Americans fully understood how serious radical Islamists are, they would demand a more confrontational strategy.}} Columnist [[Cal Thomas]] shrugged off the specter of McCarthyism, and said that the real possibility of infiltration by Islamic extremists deserves to be investigated.{{cite news |title=Suppose Michele Bachmann is right? |first=Cal |last=Thomas |url=http://www.thestate.com/2012/07/29/2371334/thomas-suppose-michele-bachmann.html |newspaper=[[The State (newspaper)|The State]] |date=29 July 2012 |accessdate=11 August 2012 |quote=Like the ghosts of Shakespeare's Banquo or Dickens' Jacob Marley, the specter of the late commie-hunting congressman from Wisconsin, Joseph McCarthy, will always be with us. It is summoned up today, by some on the left, who use it as a tool to thwart legitimate questions about people and ideologies that seek to destroy America. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120811040903/http://www.thestate.com/2012/07/29/2371334/thomas-suppose-michele-bachmann.html |archivedate=11 August 2012 |df= }} Responding to her critics, Bachmann said that "The concerns I have and my colleagues have are real," and "We cannot elevate political correctness over national security."{{cite news |title=Bachmann shuns 'political correctness' |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2012/07/31/Bachmann-shuns-political-correctness/UPI-94091343769420/ |newspaper=United Press International |date=31 July 2012 |accessdate=11 August 2012 |quote=While in Minnesota to observe work on the new St. Croix River bridge, Bachmann brushed off backlash over her speculation that U.S. Rep. Keith Ellison, D-Ind., and Huma Abedin, deputy chief of staff for Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, have ties to the Muslim Brotherhood.}} Rooney expressed similar concerns: "As a member of the House Armed Services and Intelligence committees, my top priority is ensuring the security of our nation." And that "I regret that Mrs. Abedin has become the media focus of this story, because the intention of the letters was to bring greater attention to the legitimate national security risk."{{cite news |title=Is Rep. Tom Rooney using McCarthy tactics on Muslim Brotherhood? |author=Opinion Staff |url=http://blogs.palmbeachpost.com/opinionzone/2012/07/20/is-rep-tom-rooney-using-mccarthy-tactics-on-muslim-brotherhood/ |newspaper=Palm Beach Post |date=20 July 2012 |accessdate=18 August 2012 |quote=Rep. Rooney said he was concerned about the Muslim Brotherhood's involvement in the 2009 shooting at Fort Hood, Texas, in which a Muslim Army officer murdered 13 people.}} A couple of months later, Rooney admitted that it was an unfortunate mistake to include Mrs. Abedin: "What got lost was a legitimate question, for the sake of using Congressman (Anthony) Weiner's wife and Sec. Clinton's assistant's name specifically in a letter."{{cite web|url=http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2012/sep/25/rooney-naming-hillary-clintons-chief-of-staff-a/|title=Rooney: Naming Hillary Clinton's chief of staff in a letter as potentially 'serious security concern' was a mistake|first=Jonathan|last=Mattise|date=25 September 2012 |work=TCPalm.com |publisher=Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |accessdate=28 September 2012 |quote=Rooney, R-Tequesta, reiterated the investigation's importance Tuesday, specifically regarding Department of Defense issues and the tragedy at Fort Hood.}} During an October campaign stop in Florida to support [[Mitt Romney]], John McCain acknowledged that Rooney and Bachmann had realized that including Abedin's name in the letter to the State Department was a mistake. McCain then softened his earlier criticism from the Senate floor, saying "I'm concerned, and they're concerned and I agree with them, about the influence of the Muslim Brotherhood. I'm not saying all members of the Muslim Brotherhood are extremists, but I am saying there are some extremists that are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. ... There is definitely a threat of radical Muslim extremism, some of whom are Muslim Brotherhood—not all, by far."{{cite web|last=Mattise|first=Jonathan|title=Sen. John McCain shares insights on Florida as a campaign destination, other topics|url=http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2012/oct/24/sen-john-mccain-shares-insights-on-florida-as-a/|work=TCPalm|publisher=Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers|accessdate=26 October 2012|date=24 October 2012}} ===Florida water quality=== [[File:Florida Algae Bloom 01.jpg|thumb|A Florida kayaker's paddles scoop up algae on the Santa Fe River, 2012]] Nitrogen and phosphorus pollution provide nutrients that can cause [[Algal bloom|algae blooms]], which in turn produce toxins harmful to humans and animals across the state of Florida. Approximately 1,900 miles of rivers and streams in the state were impaired for nutrients in 2010, up from approximately 1,000 miles in 2008. Impaired acres of lakes in Florida were 378,000 in 2010, up from 350,000 acres in 2008.{{cite web |title=Federal Water Quality Standards for the State of Florida |url=http://water.epa.gov/lawsregs/rulesregs/florida_index.cfm |work=Water: Regulatory Information|publisher=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency|accessdate=18 September 2012|date=31 July 2012}} ====Background==== In 2008 the public interest law firm [[Earthjustice]] sued the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] on behalf of five environmental groups, claiming that delays by both state and federal governments in establishing quantitaive (rather than qualitative) limits for [[nutrient pollution]] of Florida's waters were unacceptable. In August 2009 the Obama administration settled the lawsuit by agreeing to begin the process of imposing enforceable EPA standards for nutrient levels in the public waters of Florida.{{cite press release |url=http://earthjustice.org/news/press/2009/epa-agrees-to-set-limits-on-fertilizer-and-animal-waste-pollution-in-florida |title=EPA Agrees to Set Limits on Fertilizer and Animal Waste Pollution in Florida |date=21 August 2009 |publisher=Earthjustice |accessdate=20 August 2012 |quote=Under the administration of President George W. Bush, the EPA let the states off the hook by allowing them to formulate plans without deadlines for action.}} Numerical nutrient level standards announced in November 2010 provoked the State of Florida to fight back by suing the EPA (enraging Earthjustice and environmentalists). Florida's outgoing ([[Bill McCollum]]) and incoming ([[Pam Bondi]]) Attorneys General, as well as the outgoing ([[Charles H. Bronson]]) and incoming ([[Adam Putnam]]) Agriculture Commissioners said that the EPA standards "are not based on scientifically sound methodology, and were adopted in an arbitrary and capricious manner just to settle a lawsuit." The EPA said that the regulations would not be implemented for 15 months.{{cite news |title=Florida sues the EPA to block water pollution rules |first=Bill |last=Kaczor |url=http://www.tampabay.com/incoming/florida-sues-the-epa-to-block-water-pollution-rules/1138748 |newspaper=Tampa Bay Times |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=20 August 2012 |quote=The case was filed in the same Pensacola federal court where McCollum also is challenging President Barack Obama's health care overhaul.}}{{cite web |url=http://floridaindependent.com/16539/earthjustice-blasts-state-lawsuit-against-epa |title=Earthjustice blasts state lawsuit against EPA |first=Virginia |last=Chamlee |date=8 December 2010 |work=Florida Independent |publisher=American Independent News Network |accessdate=19 August 2012 |quote=David Guest, attorney for Earthjustice, released a statement following yesterday's announcement of the suit against the EPA. Calling the lawsuit a 'waste of taxpayer dollars,' Guest said that the state was using tax dollars to side with polluters rather than the environment.}} One year later, Earthjustice counterattacked by filing suit against the [[Florida Department of Environmental Protection]] (FDEP) claiming that the state agency had failed to protect Floridians and tourists from toxic algae outbreaks.{{cite web |url= http://earthjustice.org/news/press/2011/earthjustice-files-suit-to-protect-floridians-right-to-clean-water |title= Earthjustice Files Suit to Protect Floridians' Right to Clean Water |date= 1 December 2011 |work= Press Release |publisher= Earthjustice |accessdate= 20 August 2012 |quote= The rule that the EPA set for Florida was a 'speed limit sign' that gave everyone fair notice of what specific level of pollution would be allowed in a particular water body. If the speed limit was exceeded, regulators could take action to prevent toxic algae outbreaks and green slime. But the DEP's rule doesn't provide that certainty, and it won't protect public health.}} Judge Bram Canter of the Florida Division of Administrative Hearings ruled against the Earthjustice lawsuit in June, 2012.{{cite web |url= http://earthjustice.org/news/press/2012/floridians-lose-in-the-fight-for-clean-water |title= Floridians Lose In the Fight For Clean Water |date= 7 June 2012 |work= Press Release |publisher= Earthjustice |accessdate= 20 August 2012 |quote= This decision represents yet another failure to address Florida's worst pollution problem—sewage, manure and fertilizer in our water.}} The Obama administration then announced that EPA enforcement would be delayed until 2013, and that the EPA may defer to FDEP regulations.{{cite news |title= As the election nears, new rules are facing delays |first= Dina |last= Cappiello |url= http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2012-07-30/as-the-election-nears-new-rules-are-facing-delays |newspaper= Bloomberg Businessweek |date= 30 July 2012 |accessdate= 20 August 2012 |quote= Critics of the regulations are hoping for another election-year gift: a decision by the EPA to abandon its requirements, and instead endorse ones drafted by the state.}}{{cite news |title= Rules Delayed, Governing Denied |author= Editorial |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/12/opinion/sunday/rules-delayed-governing-denied.html |newspaper= New York Times |date= 11 August 2012 |accessdate= 20 August 2012 |quote= The E.P.A. itself has repeatedly postponed the effective date of... a rule hotly opposed by developers in a hotly contested state.}} ====Rooney challenges EPA==== After the EPA said that it would establish numeric nutrient levels for waters in the state of Florida, as part of the 2009 consent decree with Earthjustice, Rooney led the state's congressional delegation by writing a letter asking the EPA to work with the state as it formulated rules for Florida. Rooney explained:
Florida has spent over $19 million and several years collecting the necessary data, sound science and community input to develop standards that are realistic and attainable for Florida. As the EPA begins to establish nutrient levels for Florida waters, it is important for the state to be a part of the decision process and to use the invaluable information that has been collected. This bipartisan letter signed by twenty-five members of our delegation simply asks EPA to work with Florida and utilize its data."{{cite web |url= http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3021 |title= Rooney Heads Florida Delegation Request to EPA |date= 2 December 2009 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website |accessdate= 20 August 2012}}
Following the January 2010 publication of proposed EPA rules for Florida, Rooney said: "There are still too many questions that must be answered regarding the science used by the EPA."{{cite web |url= http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3007 |title= Rooney Statement on EPA Field Hearing |date= 18 February 2010 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website |accessdate= 20 August 2012}} Rooney and other members of Florida's Congressional delegation met with EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson in March, concerning the proposed Numeric Nutrient rules. At that meeting the agency agreed to extend the public comment period and to hold three more public meetings in Florida. Rooney also told Jackson that he was concerned, inasmuch as she had failed to meet personally with Florida Department of Environmental Protection Secretary Michael Sole. Rooney said: "While there was progress in some areas the EPA proposal will have massive repercussions throughout our state. Therefore, this is something we cannot rush head-first into without knowing all the facts and science."{{cite web |url= http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3005 |title= Rooney Asks for Third Party EPA Review |date= 18 February 2010 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website |accessdate= 21 August 2012 |quote=There has been great concern about the reliability and legitimacy of the science used by the EPA in setting the proposed numeric numbers. At this morning's meeting Rooney asked the EPA to help settle this dispute by having a third party study and review the science the agency used.}} Rooney pointed to studies concluding that the proposed rule would take $2 billion out of Florida's economy, and urged the EPA to do an economic analysis of the rule. He also called for the EPA to allow an independent, scientific review of the rule, which the EPA refused to do.{{cite web |url= http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2011/feb/21/tom-rooney-untested-proposed-epa-regulations-not/ |title= Untested proposed EPA regulations might not clean Florida's water, but will dramatically drive up costs for residents and businesses |first= Tom |last= Rooney |date= 21 February 2011 |work= TCPalm.com |publisher= Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |accessdate= 20 August 2012 |quote= I will not allow EPA to act tyrannically and dictatorially on this issue that affects every Floridian. Until the EPA is willing to consider Florida's unique needs and its economy, this regulation must not go into effect.}} An April, 2010 report by the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, in conjunction with professors at the University of Florida Food and Resource Economics Department, and with Soil and Water Engineering Technology, Inc. concluded that compliance with the proposed numeric nutrient rule would subject 13.6 million acres of agriculture to direct costs of from $902 million to $1.605 billion annually, and indirect economic impacts of $1.148 billion per year to the state of Florida. "This report confirms what we have all feared. The economic ramifications of this proposed rule would be devastating to our state," Rooney said.{{cite web |url= http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2977 |title= Rooney: Proposed EPA Numeric Nutrient Rule "Devastating" for Florida Economy |date= 22 April 2010 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website |accessdate= 21 August 2012}} In August, Rooney again called for delay of final federal rulemaking, pending the results of a third-party analysis, in a bipartisan letter from Florida's Congressional delegation to Lisa Jackson.{{cite web |url= http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2911 |title= Rooney Calls for Independent Analysis of Numeric Nutrient Proposal |date= 1 August 2010 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website |accessdate= 21 August 2012}} In September, a federal judge temporarily stopped the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers from imposing federal water quality standards on former croplands in the Everglades, ruling that the Corps had changed its rules about water quality standards on former croplands without proper public notice and hearing.{{cite news |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/state-regional/federal-judge-halts-army-corps-efforts-to-clean-up/nMBNQ/ |title= Federal judge halts Army Corps' efforts to clean up former cropland in Everglades |last= Stapleton |first= Christine |date= 29 September 2010 |newspaper= Palm Beach Post |accessdate= 3 September 2012 |quote=Nutrient standards—especially in the Everglades—have been especially controversial lately as two federal judges have ordered water managers and environmental officials to enforce nutrient standards and speed up the Everglades cleanup.}} In December, 2010, Florida Attorney General Bill McCollum and Attorney General-elect Pam Bondi decided to file a lawsuit against the EPA regarding its proposed numeric nutrient rule. Rooney endorsed that decision, saying that "this lawsuit will put a stop to the EPA's misguided assaults on Florida's families and industries." Senator George LeMieux also endorsed the legal challenge to the EPA rule for Florida.{{cite web|url=http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3121|title= Rooney, LeMieux Support Florida Lawsuit against EPA|date= 7 December 2010|work= Press Release|publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website|accessdate= 21 August 2012}} ====Cooperation, criticism and compromise==== After Lisa Jackson appeared before the House Agriculture Committee in March 2011, Rooney said: "In all the hearings I've attended as a member of Congress, I've never been to one like Lisa Jackson's appearance before the House Agriculture Committee. All the members of the committee—Republicans and Democrats—were up in arms over the EPA's agenda. I've never seen a witness from the administration get attacked like that from members of the president's own party."{{cite news|last=Ward|first=Kenric|title=EPA Boss Lisa Jackson in Hot Water Over Job-Killing Policies Florida businesses, and even Democrats, challenge chief on science, economy|url=http://www.sunshinestatenews.com/story/epa-boss-lisa-jackson-hot-water-over-job-killing-policies|accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=Sunshine State News|date=27 June 2011|quote=Under the leadership of Lisa Jackson, the EPA has alternately antagonized and disappointed business leaders and environmentalists.}} Rooney sent a letter thanking Jackson for her promise that the EPA would cooperate with the state of Florida (and their Congressional delegation) to come up with reasonable nutrient levels, and for allowing both scientific review and economic analysis of the new regulations. Rooney's letter also asked the following questions:{{cite web |url= http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3181 |title= Rooney Thanks EPA Administrator for Commitment to Work with Florida on Numeric Nutrient Compromise |date= 11 March 2011 |work= Press Release |publisher= Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website |accessdate= 21 August 2012}} * When will EPA begin to produce a complete economic analysis of the impact of the proposed regulation, and when does EPA expect that analysis to be complete? * What methodology will EPA use in its economic analysis? * Which third-party organization will EPA task with conducting a thorough review of the proposed rule? * When will that third-party review commence, and when does EPA expect it to conclude? * How will EPA adjust the proposed regulation to accommodate the findings of the third-party review and economic analysis? Rooney and Senator Marco Rubio were criticised in the press for "siding with polluters" and "greedy business interests," leading Rooney and Rubio to co-author an article explaining that "half of the Democrats in Florida's House delegation supported our amendment to prevent the EPA from enforcing this new mandate until they complete an independent study of the science and a thorough economic analysis" and that Lisa Jackson had recently committed to having the EPA work with Florida's DEP.{{cite web |url= http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2011/mar/18/editorial-rooney-and-rubio-join-forces-to-fight/ |title= Editorial: Rooney and Rubio join forces to fight EPA over clean water regulations for Florida |author= Editorial board |date= 18 March 2011 |work= TCPalm.com |publisher= Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |accessdate= 21 August 2012}} {{cite web |url= http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2011/mar/29/marco-rubio-tom-rooney-why-were-fighting-the-job/ |title= Marco Rubio and Tom Rooney: Why we're fighting the EPA's job-destroying water mandate |first1= Marco |last1= Rubio |first2= Tom |last2= Rooney |date= 29 March 2011 |work= TCPalm.com |publisher= Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |accessdate= 21 August 2012}} Although the Rooney amendment was eventually dropped, the EPA agreed to a one-year delay of new water rules and that the [[National Academy of Sciences]] would conduct an unbiased review of the EPA cost estimate.{{cite web|title=A bipartisan effort forces EPA to delay, again, new water rules for Florida|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/content/bipartisan-effort-forces-epa-delay-again-new-water-rules-florida|work=The Buzz (blog)|publisher=Tampa Bay Times|accessdate=18 September 2012|date=11 April 2011|quote=A raft of policy riders were dropped from the budget deal approved late Friday, including one that would have prevented the Environmental Protection Agency from enforcing controversial new clean water standards in Florida. But the rules are on hold anyway.}}{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Lisa|title=Letter to Sen. Bill Nelson|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/sites/tampabay.com.blogs.the-buzz-florida-politics/files/nelson.pdf|accessdate=18 September 2012|format=PDF|date=6 April 2011}}{{cite web|first=Tom|last=Rooney|url=http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3207|title=Rooney: EPA Agreement to Study Cost of Numeric Nutrient Mandate a Good Start|date =11 April 2011|work=Press Release|publisher =Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website|accessdate=21 August 2012|quote=Florida's Department of Environmental Protection, the Chamber of Commerce, the League of Cities, and the Farm Bureau, along with the EPA, all deserve to be part of this process.}} Rooney was criticized in an editorial for voting for a House bill sponsored by [[John Mica]] that would prohibit tightening water pollutant limits without a state's consent, a bill that the EPA protested would "overturn almost 40 years of federal legislation by preventing EPA from protecting public health and water quality."{{cite web |url= http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2011/aug/01/editorial-proposal-in-us-senate-would-weaken-in/ |title= Editorial: Proposal in U.S. Senate would weaken efforts in Florida, nationwide to clean up waterways |author= Editorial board |date= 1 August 2011 |work= TCPalm.com |publisher= Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |accessdate= 20 August 2012|quote=Rooney, citing multiple concerns, including those about the potential cost to business and agriculture, has actively supported legislation that would block the EPA from implementing numerical limits to nitrogen and phosphorus in state waters under the federal Clean Water Act. This is disconcerting given that Rooney also portrays himself as a champion of the St. Lucie River and Indian River Lagoon.}} In an October 2011 column, Rooney justified congressional review of EPA regulations, reduction of red tape and interference with new mandates as a means to "get the federal government off the backs of famers."{{cite news| url= http://www2.highlandstoday.com/news/agri-leader/2011/oct/12/LRNEWSO6-cutting-through-farm-red-tape-ar-303179/|title= Cutting through farm red tape|last=Rooney|first=Tom|date=12 October 2011|newspaper=Highlands Today|accessdate=21 August 2012|quote=...the high costs of excessive government regulation and red tape are threatening to drive farmers out of business. Small farmers, who have fewer resources to keep up with the growing number of federal mandates, are being hit especially hard.}} Rooney welcomed amended rules for numeric nutrient standards, approved in December by the [[Florida Environmental Regulation Commission]] and submitted to the EPA. After final approval by the EPA, the federal standards would then be withdrawn. The EPA acknowledged that "states have the primary role in establishing and implementing water quality standards for their waters."{{cite web|url=http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3318|title=Rooney Applauds Florida Environmental Commission Approval of Reasonable Numeric Nutrient Standards|date =8 December 2011|work=Press Release|publisher =Congressman Thomas J. Rooney Website|accessdate=21 August 2012|quote=By bringing all sides to the table, as I and others have advocated, Florida was able to reach a compromise that I think everyone can support.}} In June 2012, Florida submitted, and the EPA approved, a plan to improve water quality in the Everglades.{{cite web|title=Florida Moving Forward with Plan to Improve Water Quality in America's Everglades|url=http://depnewsroom.wordpress.com/2012/06/13/florida-moving-forward-with-plan-to-improve-water-quality-in-americas-everglades/|work=DEP News|publisher=WordPress.com|accessdate=18 September 2012|author=MsNicolePR|date=13 June 2012}}{{cite web|title=Letter to Gwendolyn Keyes Fleming|url=http://www.dep.state.fl.us/secretary/news/2012/06/vinyard_letter_epa_admin_fleming.pdf|accessdate=18 September 2012|author=Herschel T. Vinyard Jr.|format=PDF|date=6 June 2012}}{{cite web|title=Letter to Herschel T. Vinyard Jr.|url=http://www.dep.state.fl.us/secretary/news/2012/06/fleming_response_revised_permit_061312.pdf|accessdate=18 September 2012|author=Gwendolyn Keyes Fleming|format=PDF|date=13 June 2012}} === Tax reform === Rooney voted in favor of the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]].{{cite web|last1=Almukhtar|first1=Sarah|title=How Each House Member Voted on the Tax Bill|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/12/19/us/politics/tax-bill-house-live-vote.html?_r=0|website=The New York Times|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=19 December 2017}} The bill includes disaster relief aid for Florida citrus growers who suffered loss due to [[Hurricane Irma]], which Rooney calls a "big win."{{cite web|title=Tuesday's Daily Pulse|url=http://www.floridatrend.com/article/23604/tuesdays-daily-pulse|website=Florida Trend|accessdate=24 December 2017}} ===Gun policy=== Rooney characterizes himself as a "champion for [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Second Amendment]] rights," saying that the right to bear arms is "one of our most sacred rights."{{cite web| url=http://www.tomrooney.com/single-post/2016/03/01/Protecting-the-Second-Amendment| title=Protecting the Second Amendment| date=1 March 2016| website=tomrooney.com| publisher=Tom Rooney for Congress| access-date=6 March 2018}} As of 2017, Rooney has an "A-" rating from the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]], indicating a voting record that is generally pro-gun rights.{{cite web| url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/107800/tom-rooney?categoryId=37&type=V,S,R,E,F,P#.Wp7tQ-dG1PY| title=Tom Rooney's Political Summary on Issue: Guns| website=ISPY| publisher=Vote Smart| access-date=6 March 2018}} As a Congressman, Rooney has voted in favor of several pieces of legislation to expand gun rights, including a yes vote on [https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/38 H. R. 38] (the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act), which would enable [[Concealed carry in the United States#Reciprocity|concealed carry reciprocity]] among all States if and when it is signed into law.{{cite web| url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2017/roll663.xml| title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 663| website=clerk.house.gov|publisher=U.S. Federal Government|date=6 December 2017| access-date=5 March 2018}} Of the Act, Rooney said, "Just as a driver's license would be recognized in another state, a person who is legally permitted to carry a concealed handgun for their or their loved ones' own protection should have that ability anywhere in our nation."{{cite web| url=https://rooney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rooney-house-pass-national-concealed-carry-reciprocity-act| title=Rooney, House Pass National Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act| website=Thomas J. Rooney| publisher=U. S. Federal Government}} In March 2017, Rooney voted in favor of the [https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/1181 Veterans Second Amendment Protection Act], which, if signed into law, will allow [[veteran]]s who are considered "mentally incompetent" to purchase ammunition and firearms unless declared a danger by a judge.{{cite web| url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2017/roll169.xml| title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 169| website=clerk.house.gov|publisher=U.S. Federal Government|date=16 March 2017| access-date=5 March 2018}} Rooney also voted in favor of [https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-joint-resolution/40 H.J.Res.40], which successfully used the [[Congressional Review Act]] to [[Repeal of the Implementation of the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007|block implementation]] of an Obama-era Amendment to the [[NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007]] that was aimed at preventing the mentally-infirm from legally purchasing firearms.{{cite web| url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2017/roll077.xml| website=clerk.house.gov|publisher=U. S. Federal Government| date=2 February 2017| access-date=6 March 2018| title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 77}} In 2015, Rooney signed a letter to the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]] objecting to a proposed ban of [[.223 Remington|a certain rifle cartridge]] due to its [[Armor-piercing shell#Small arms|armor-piercing]] capabilities.{{cite web| url=https://woodall.house.gov/sites/woodall.house.gov/files/ATFLETTER.pdf| title=Letter to B. Todd Jones, Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives - Ammunition Ban| date=4 March 2015| website=Congressman Rob Woodall| publisher=U. S. Federal Government| access-date=6 March 2018}}{{cite web| title=ATF Director B. Todd Jones Stepping Down After Nearly 4 Years on Job | url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/atf-director-todd-jones-stepping-years-job/story?id=29779602| last1=Date| first1=Jack| last2=Levine| first2=Mike| date=20 March 2015}} In the letter, it states that "the idea that Congress intended [https://www.congress.gov/bill/99th-congress/house-bill/3132 LEOPA] to ban one of the preeminent rifle cartridges in use by Americans for legitimate purposes is preposterous." The attempt to ban the cartridges was abandoned shortly thereafter. Rooney opened up more about his opinions on gun [[lobbying|lobbyist]] groups after his February 2018 announcement that he would not be seeking reelection. Rooney stated that even supporting a [[Bump fire#Bump fire stocks|bump stock]] ban after the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]] was akin to "political suicide" and that "the NRA has an extremely sophisticated ability to either help you or hurt you from being able to continue to call yourself 'Congressman.'"{{cite news| url=https://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/cerabino-fla-congressman-reveals-nra-scorecard-not-the-whole-score/xCyiZ53GJ7uZCkMzwYsK5N/| title=Cerabino: Fla. Congressman reveals NRA scorecard not the whole score| last=Cerabino| first=Frank| work=Palm Beach Post| location=Palm Beach County, Florida| access-date=6 March 2018}} Rooney also questioned the role of [[AR-15 style rifle]]s in society, saying "What is the purpose of that gun, especially one with a bump stock on it?" ==Personal life== Tom Rooney is a grandson of Pittsburgh Steelers founder [[Art Rooney]] Sr.,[http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/jan/18/are-you-ready-for-smashmouth-football/ Rep. Tom Rooney: Are you ready for some smashmouth football?] a nephew of [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] owner and ambassador to Ireland [[Dan Rooney]], and a first cousin, once removed, of actresses [[Kate Mara]] and [[Rooney Mara]].{{cite news |title=Heard on the Hill: Six Degrees of Tom Rooney |first=Neda |last=Semanani |url=http://www.rollcall.com/issues/57_78/heard_hill_six_degrees_tom_rooney-211393-1.html |newspaper=Roll Call |date=9 January 2012 |accessdate=8 August 2012 |quote=The Florida Republican is related to, um, maybe everyone on the Eastern Seaboard, or at least most everyone involved in the National Football League.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.geni.com/blog/family-tree-tuesday-rooney-mara-375297.html |title=Rooney Mara |author=Hiromimarie |date=5 June 2012 |work=Family Tree Tuesday |publisher=Geni Blog |accessdate=8 August 2012 |quote=Mara is the great-granddaughter of both New York Giants founder Tim Mara and Pittsburgh Steelers founder Art Rooney, Sr.}} Rooney's younger brother, Brian J. Rooney, has a seat on the Pittsburgh Steelers Board of Directors which was previously held by their father. Brian, a veteran of the Iraq War, is a Deputy Director of [[Michigan Department of Human Services]], and was a candidate in 2010 for Congress in [[Michigan's 7th congressional district]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.postonpolitics.com/2010/04/burn-notice-gops-west-raises-and-spends-big-in-klein-challenge/ |title=Burn notice: GOP's West raises and spends big in Klein challenge |last=Bennett |first=George |date=16 April 2010 |work=Post On Politics Blog |publisher=Palm Beach Post |accessdate=8 August 2012}}{{cite web|title=Brian Rooney Deputy Director, Policy and Compliance|url=http://www.michigan.gov/dhs/0,1687,7-124-5459_62220-282497--,00.html|work=Department of Human Services|publisher=Michigan.gov|accessdate=26 October 2012}}{{cite news|last=Gautz|first=Chris|title=Governor-elect Rick Snyder taps former Brian Rooney, former 7th District GOP candidate, to help lead Human Services Department|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/jackson/index.ssf/2010/12/snyder_taps_former_brian_roone.html|accessdate=26 October 2012|newspaper=Jackson Citizen Patriot|date=30 December 2010}} Tom's older brother, [[Patrick Rooney, Jr.]], serves in the Florida House of Representatives in District 83. {{cite news |title=Tom and Pat aren't the only Rooney candidates |first=George |last=Bennett |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/tom-and-pat-arent-the-only-rooney-candidates/nL4fr/ |newspaper=Palm Beach Post |date=15 February 2012 |accessdate=8 August 2012 |quote=Four other Rooney siblings are not seeking office.}} {{cite web|url=http://www.myfloridahouse.gov/sections/representatives/details.aspx?MemberId=4516&SessionId=66|work=Patrick Rooney, Jr. Biography|accessdate=6 August 2011|title=Florida House of Representatives}} Tom, Tara and their three sons (Tommy, Sean, Seamus) formerly split their time between Tequesta, Florida and Washington, D.C.{{cite web |url=http://rooney.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3081 |title=About Tom |work=Congressional Website |accessdate=8 August 2012}} Rooney decided to run in the new District 17, and he promised to move into that district, but told ''[[The Ledger]]'' that he and his wife had not yet decided on which city.{{cite news |title=The Ledger Recommends – U.S. Representative Dist. 17: Tom Rooney |url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20120806/EDIT01/120809676/-1/news22 |newspaper=The Ledger |date=6 August 2012 |accessdate=8 August 2012}} Rooney planned to move to [[Charlotte County, Florida|Charlotte County]], but he said that "I'm leaving where I grew up. That's the hardest thing." Charlotte County has the largest percentage of voters in the newly-drawn district, and includes the city of [[Punta Gorda, Florida|Punta Gorda]] (where Rooney has his campaign office and one of his Congressional offices) as well as the larger, but unincorporated [[Port Charlotte, Florida|Port Charlotte]] as well as other unincorporated communities.{{cite web |url=http://tomrooney.com/connect.php |title=Connect |work=Tom Rooney for Congress |accessdate=13 August 2012}}{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=Zac|title=Rep. Rooney says he's willing to compromise to reach debt deal|url=http://politics.heraldtribune.com/2012/10/31/rep-rooney-says-hes-willing-to-compromise-to-reach-debt-deal/|accessdate=1 November 2012|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|date=31 October 2012|quote=The 41-year-old Republican from Palm Beach County is a heavy favorite to win a third term in a newly drawn district that sprawls across the state to include part of Manatee County and all of Charlotte. Rooney's sense of urgency stems from his belief that the country is running out of time to address the national debt.}} The Rooneys ended up selling their Tequesta home and purchasing a home in [[Okeechobee, Florida|Okeechobee]]. ===Palm Beach Kennel Club=== Tom's grandfather, Art Rooney, bought the Palm Beach Kennel Club in West Palm Beach in 1969 and his father ran the business as president from 1984 until recently, when his brother, Patrick J. Rooney Jr., became president of the club.{{cite web |url= http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2008-08-16/news/0808150281_1_charlie-crist-gambling-interests-endorsement |title= Crist backs Rooney for Congress |first= Jim |last= Turner |date= 16 August 2008 |work= Sun Sentinel |publisher= Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |accessdate= 2 September 2012 |quote=As part of the growing bitterness in the race, the Kennel Club's president, Pat Rooney Sr., the candidate's father, has threatened Valeche with a lawsuit over a newspaper editorial in which Valeche criticized the kennel club's proposal to expand gambling.}}{{cite news |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/sports/rooney-family-has-made-a-big-impact-in-palm-beach-/nLphQ/ |title= Rooney family has made a big impact in Palm Beach County |first= Brian |last= Biggane |date= 3 February 2011 |newspaper= Palm Beach Post |accessdate= 2 September 2012 |quote=PBKC remained the main family business here. Last year, it was the nation's No. 1 dog track in terms of money wagered at $199 million counting both live and simulcast.}} Tom Rooney lists ownership of stock in family businesses in his congressional financial disclosure form. Rooney has said that he has neither operational nor ownership responsibilities, and the stock is part of a trust with his children as beneficiaries.{{cite news |url= http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/palm-beach-county-voters-will-decide-on-slots-in-n/nL2b9/ |title= Palm Beach County voters will decide on slots in November |last= Abramson |first= Andrew |date= 20 December 2011 |newspaper= Palm Beach Post |accessdate= 18 August 2012}} In 2010, Rooney stood at 346th place in terms of net worth among the members of the U.S. House.{{cite web |url= |title=In wealth, only 1 of 3 Treasure Coast House members in upper half |work= TCPalm.com |first= Trish |last= Choates |date= 17 March 2010 |publisher= Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers |quote=In 2008, Rooney drew an income of $88,860 with the Stuart law firm of Kramer, Sopko and Levenstein, his 14.3 percent shares with the Patrick J. Rooney Jr. Irrevocable Trust, which owns the Palm Beach Kennel Club, the Patrick J. Rooney Sr. family trust, and a family trust involved in real estate development in Pittsburgh, are worth a combined $166,004 to $415,000.}} The Palm Beach Kennel Club serves the product of yet another family business, Rooney's Old Irish Ale.{{cite web |url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2008-08-16/news/0808150281_1_charlie-crist-gambling-interests-endorsement |title= Frequently Asked Questions |work= Rooney's Beer |publisher= Rooney's Beer Co., LLC, Pittsburgh, PA. |accessdate= 2 September 2012 |quote=From'99 to present, the Rooney's Old Irish Ale has been served and enjoyed exclusively at Florida family businesses: Rooney's Public House (Jupiter, FL), Rooney's Public House (PB International Airport), Rooney's All-In Sports Bar & Grille, (West Palm Beach, FL) and the Palm Beach Kennel Club (West Palm Beach, FL).}} The Palm Beach County Commission has approved a referendum for the November 2012 ballot to decide whether [[slot machine]]s will be allowed at the Palm Beach Kennel Club.{{cite news |url= http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2011-12-20/news/fl-slots-referendum-palm-20111220_1_slot-full-fledged-casinos-gambling |title= Palm Beach County to hold slot machine referendum |last= Reid |first= Andy |date= 20 December 2011 |newspaper= Sun Sentinel |accessdate= 18 August 2012 |quote=The kennel club owners, the influential Rooney family, have lobbied for years to get slot machines and other expanded gaming.}} Tom's cousin Joe Rooney is a spokesman for, as well as Co-Chair and Treasurer of the coalition supporting the Palm Beach County slot machines referendum.{{cite web|title=Leadership Team|url=http://www.voteyesforslots.com/about-us/leadership-team/|work=Vote Yes for Slot Machines in Palm Beach County|publisher=Coalition for More Jobs, Better Schools and a Stronger Economy|accessdate=24 September 2012}} Other Florida counties have put slot machine referendums on the November ballot, but Attorney General Palm Bondi issued an opinion that current state law does not allow slots outside of Miami-Dade and Broward counties.{{cite news|title=Group hopes to bring slot machines to Palm Beach County|url=http://www.wpbf.com/news/south-florida/Palm-Beach-County-News/Group-hopes-to-bring-slot-machines-to-Palm-Beach-County/-/8815578/16651428/-/format/rsss_2.0/-/y9h96qz/-/index.html|accessdate=24 September 2012|newspaper=WPBF-TV|date=18 September 2012}} Joe Rooney said Palm Beach County will have several paths to follow if the referendum succeeds, including legislation and legal action.{{cite news|last=Sortal|first=Nick|title=Palm Beach Kennel Club revs up slot campaign|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-09-19/entertainment/sfl-palm-beach-kennel-club-revs-up-slot-campaign-20120919_1_slot-campaign-palm-beach-kennel-club-tax-revenue|accessdate=24 September 2012|newspaper=Sun Sentinel|date=19 September 2012}} ==Movies== In 2014 Rooney made a cameo appearance as a farmer in [[Walt Before Mickey]] starring [[Thomas Ian Nicholas]], [[Jon Heder]], {{Other uses}} {{more citations needed|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = William Dawes Jr. | image = William Dawes.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth-date|6 April 1745}} | birth_place = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1799|2|25|1745|4|5|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Marlborough, Massachusetts]] | occupation = Tanner | spouse = Mehitable May (1768–1793; divorce)
Lydia Gendall | parents = William and Lydia Dawes | children = 6 with Mehitable May
1 with Lydia Gendall }} '''William Dawes Jr.''' (April 6, 1745 – February 25, 1799) was one of several men and a woman''Paul Revere's Ride'' by David Hackett Fischer in April 1775 who alerted [[Thirteen Colonies|colonial]] [[Minutemen (militia)|minutemen]] in Massachusetts of the approach of [[British army]] troops prior to the [[Battles of Lexington and Concord]] at the outset of the [[American Revolution]].{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/news/the-midnight-ride-of-william-dawes?linkId=23506843|title=The Midniight Ride of William Dawes|last=Klein|first=Christopher|date=April 18, 2012|publisher=History.com|accessdate=24 October 2017}} For some years, [[Paul Revere]] had the most renown for his ride of warning of this event. ==Early life== Dawes was born in Boston, Massachusetts, on April 6, 1745, to William and Lydia Dawes ([[née]] Boone), and baptized at Boston's [[Old South Meeting House|Old South Church]]. He became a [[Tanning (leather)|tanner]] and was active in Boston's militia. On May 3, 1768, Dawes married Mehitable May, the daughter of Samuel and Catherine May (née Mears). The ''[[Boston Gazette]]'' noted that for his wedding, he wore a suit entirely made in North America. At the time, [[Radical Whigs|Whigs]] were trying to organize a boycott of British products to pressure [[Parliament of Great Britain|Parliament]] into repealing the [[Townshend Acts]]. ==Role in Boston's militia== On April 8, 1768, Dawes was elected as a member of the [[Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Massachusetts]]. He was appointed as the Company's second sergeant in 1770. When the Company was revived in 1786, after becoming dormant during the American Revolution, he was appointed as the Company clerk. His father, William Dawes Sr., was also a member of the Company. It is likely that in September 1774, Dawes was instrumental in helping Boston's militia artillery company secure its four small cannons from British army control. The [[Massachusetts]] [[Provincial Congress]] certainly sent word to him in February 1775 that it was time to move two of those weapons out of Boston. ===Midnight ride=== Dawes was assigned by Doctor [[Joseph Warren]] to ride from [[Boston]] to [[Lexington, Massachusetts]], on the night of April 18, 1775, when it became clear that a British column was going to march into the countryside. Dawes's mission was to warn [[John Hancock]] and [[Samuel Adams]] that they were in danger of arrest. Dawes took the land route out of Boston through the [[Boston Neck]], leaving just before the British military sealed off the town.{{cite web|url=http://www.wmdawes.org/ride.html|title=The Ride|publisher=The Descendants of William Dawes Who Rode Association|accessdate=1 December 2012}} Also acting under Dr. Warren, [[Paul Revere]] arranged for another rider waiting across the Charles River in Charlestown to be told of the army's route with lanterns hung in [[Old North Church]]. To be certain the message would get through, Revere rowed across the river and started riding westward himself. Later, [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]]'s historically inaccurate poem "[[Paul Revere's Ride (poem)|Paul Revere's Ride]]" would focus entirely on Revere, making him a composite of the many alarm riders that night. Dawes and Revere arrived at the [[Hancock-Clarke House]] in Lexington about the same time, shortly after midnight. Revere arrived slightly earlier, despite having stopped to speak to militia officers in towns along the way, as his route was shorter and his horse faster. After warning Adams and Hancock to leave, Revere and Dawes proceeded to [[Concord, Massachusetts|Concord]] in case that was the British column's goal. Revere no doubt knew that the Provincial Congress had stored munitions there, including the cannon which Dawes had helped to secure. Along the way, the two men met [[Samuel Prescott]], a local young physician, who joined them. A squad of mounted British officers awaited on the road between Lexington and Concord. They had already arrested some riders heading west with news of the troops, and they called for Dawes, Revere, and Prescott to halt. The three men rode in different directions, hoping one would escape. Dawes, according to the story he told his children, rode into the yard of a house shouting that he had lured two officers there. Fearing an ambush, the officers stopped chasing him. Dawes's horse bucked him off, however, and he had to walk back to Lexington. He later said that in the morning, he returned to the same yard and found the watch that had fallen from his pocket. Otherwise, Dawes's activity during the Battle of Lexington and Concord remains unknown. Dawes and his companions' warnings allowed the town militias to muster a sufficient force for the first open battle of the [[American Revolutionary War]] and the first colonial victory. The British troops did not find most of the weapons they had marched to destroy, and sustained serious losses during their retreat to Boston while under attack by the colonists. ===Service in the American Revolution=== On September 9, 1776 Dawes was commissioned second major of the Boston militia regiment. Also during the war, Dawes worked as a quartermaster in central Massachusetts. British [[POW]]s from the [[Battle of Saratoga]] complained to [[Parliament of Great Britain|Parliament]] that he gave them short supplies; his family countered that Dawes believed that they were stealing from farmers while being marched to Boston – as most armies on the march were prone to do. ==Later life and death== [[File:William Dawes tomb Boston.jpg|thumb|right|280px|William Dawes tomb marker in [[King's Chapel Burying Ground]]]] Dawes refused to join a punitive expedition against Indians ordered by Governor Phillip in December 1790. Mehitable died in 1793,{{cite web |url=http://www.wmdawes.org/wmdawesburial.html |title=Who's buried in Dawes's tomb? |first=Ron |last=Fletcher |publisher=Boston Globe |date=2005-02-25}} but he remarried (to Lydia) two years later. Dawes died in [[Marlborough, Massachusetts]], on February 25, 1799. He was believed to have been buried in the [[King's Chapel Burying Ground]], but modern research points to his resting place now being in his first wife's family plot in [[Forest Hills Cemetery]] in [[Jamaica Plain]]. ==Legacy== {{Main|Paul Revere#The Midnight Ride of Paul Revere}} [[File:1510-Cambridge Common 095.jpg|thumbnail|Memorial: William Dawes to Lexington. Location: Harvard Square, Cambridge, Massachusetts]] The poem by [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]], "[[Paul Revere's Ride (poem)|Paul Revere's Ride]]", has been criticized by modern historians for overstating the role of Revere in the night's events. Revere's may have been a better story, but Dawes and Prescott were more successful in achieving their missions. In 1896 Helen F. Moore, dismayed that William Dawes had been forgotten, penned a parody of Longfellow's poem.{{cite web|url = http://www.paul-revere-heritage.com/midnight-ride-william-dawes.html | title = The Midnight Ride of William Dawes}} [[File:William Dawes plaque, Cambridge, MA - IMG 4611.JPG|thumbnail|left|William Dawes plaque showing the route his ride. Near Cambridge Commons, [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].]] The difference in Revere's and Dawes's achievement and legacy is examined by [[Malcolm Gladwell]] in his book ''[[The Tipping Point]]'', where he concludes that Revere would be classified as a [[Connector (social)|connector]] whereas Dawes was an "ordinary man." Dawes's ride is commemorated on a traffic island in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], heavily travelled by pedestrians, at the intersection of Garden Street and [[Massachusetts Avenue (Boston)|Massachusetts Avenue]] in [[Harvard Square]], and known as ''Dawes Island''. Dawes's passage through the area is represented by bronze horseshoes embedded in the sidewalk, as hoofprints, accompanied by an inscription giving his name and the date (inaccurately stated as April 19, 1775), and by historical displays.{{cite web|url=http://www.wmdawes.org/dawesisland.html|title=Dawes Island|publisher=The Descendants of William Dawes Who Rode Association|accessdate=1 December 2012}}"The American Revolution Comes to Cambridge, Part II: Sounding the Warning: 18–19 April 1775", Note 3, {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507044401/http://www2.cambridgema.gov/Historic/april1.html |date=May 7, 2011 }} Retrieved 1 May 2016. In the film ''[[Knowing (film)|Knowing]]'', the early events take place in [[Lexington, Massachusetts]], at William Dawes Elementary School. ==Descendants== William Dawes' great-grandson, [[Rufus Dawes]], was a [[American Civil War|Civil War]] military officer and congressman. Rufus Dawes' children included [[Charles G. Dawes]], who served as [[Vice President of the United States]] under [[Calvin Coolidge]], [[Rufus C. Dawes]], a businessman, [[Beman Gates Dawes]], a businessman and congressman, and [[Henry M. Dawes]], a businessman and banker. Television personality [[Bill Schulz]] is another descendant of Dawes, as the grandson of Henry M. Dawes' daughter Mary.{{cite web | title=Mary Dawes is Wed in Ceremony at Parents' Home | last=Cass | first=Judith | work=Chicago Sunday Tribune | date=September 24, 1933 | url=http://archive.lib.msu.edu/DMC/tribune/trib09241933/trib09241933003.pdf }} William Dawes was also a first cousin of [[Thomas Dawes]], who was a Revolutionary War colonel, a noted architect/builder, and held numerous government positions. ==See also== * The [[Charles G. Dawes House]] has portraits of William Dawes and his wife, Mehitable May, in its collection. * The [[Dawes Arboretum]] also has a portrait of William Dawes in its collection. * [[Israel Bissell]] * [[Sybil Ludington]] ==References== ==Further reading== * David Hackett Fischer, ''Paul Revere's Ride'', Oxford University Press, 1995. == External links == * [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/1870 William Dawes' grave] at findagrave.com. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dawes, William}} [[Category:1745 births]] [[Category:1799 deaths]] [[Category:American Congregationalists|Dawes,William]] [[Category:Massachusetts militiamen in the American Revolution]] [[Category:People from colonial Boston]] [[Category:People of Massachusetts in the American Revolution]] [[Category:People of colonial Massachusetts]] [[Category:Dawes family]] [[Category:Burials in Boston]]

Esfira Rapaport | relatives = }} '''Yossi Maiman''' (born [[February 8]], [[1946]]) also known as '''Josef Maiman''', is a German-born Israeli businessman. He is the founder and owner of the [[Merhav Group]], and a shareholder of the [[East Mediterranean Gas Company]]. He is a former majority shareholder of [[Channel 10 (Israel)|Channel 10]], an Israeli television channel. He is the former owner, chairman, chief executive officer and president of the [[Ampal-American Israel Corporation]]. ==Early life== Yossi Maiman was born in a [[displaced persons camp]] in [[Landsberg am Lech]], [[Bavaria]], [[Germany]].{{cite news|last1=Lefkovitz|first1=Etgar|title=94-year-old Holocaust survivor reconnects with family that saved her life|url=http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/94-year-old-Holocaust-survivor-reconnects-with-family-that-saved-her-life|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=September 18, 2008}} He is of [[Polish Jews|Polish Jewish descent]] on his maternal side. His mother, Esfira Maiman, is a Holocaust survivor from [[Lodz]]; she escaped from the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] and hid in [[Grodzisk Mazowiecki]] during [[World War II]]. Her first husband was murdered by the Nazis. (In 2008, the Roman Catholic woman who saved her, Stanislawa Slawinska, was honored by [[Yad Vashem]] as [[Righteous Among the Nations]].{{cite news|last1=Sudilovsky|first1=Judith|title=Catholic to be honored posthumously for saving Jews during Holocaust|url=http://www.catholicvoiceoakland.org/2008/08-10-06/inthisissue12.htm|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=The Catholic Voice|date=October 6, 2008}}) After she remarried to Maiman's father, the family moved to [[Peru]], where Maiman grew up. They emigrated to Israel in 1972. Maiman graduated with a bachelor's degree in economics from the [[University of Texas at El Paso]].{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Merhav MNF Ltd.: Yosef A. Maiman|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=2971160&privcapId=27407576|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=October 21, 2016}} He earned a master of arts degree in economics from [[Cornell University]]. ==Career== Maiman founded the [[Merhav Group]] in 1975.{{cite news|title=Israel's Richest: #18 Yosef A. Maiman|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/81/biz_06israel_Yosef-A-Maiman_MPSN.html|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=Forbes|date=December 11, 2012}} He serves its president and chief executive officer. Through a subsidiary, it invests in sugarcane and ethanol production,{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Merhav MNF Ltd.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=27407576|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=October 21, 2016}} It also owns a concession from the Egyptian government to export natural gas to Israel. Additionally, it "modernized a refinery in [[Turkmenistan]]" and a "water treatment and sewage systems in [[Venezuela]]". Maiman acquired the [[Ampal-American Israel Corporation]] from [[Beny Steinmetz]] for US $174 million in 2002.{{cite news|last1=Levy|first1=Aviv|last2=Steinblatt|first2=Ron|title=Yosef Maiman set to leave Ampal|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000824465|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=Globes|date=February 21, 2013}} He served as its chairman from 2002 to 2013, and as its president and chief executive officer from 2006 to 2013. According to ''[[Globes]]'', Maiman stepped down as a result of losses incurred in the wake of the [[Egyptian revolution of 2011]], when contracts for the distribution of gas between Egypt and Israel fell through. Maiman invested in [[Channel 10 (Israel)|Channel 10]], an Israeli television channel, in 2003, becoming the largest shareholder alongside [[Arnon Milchan]], [[Ron Lauder]] and [[Rupert Murdoch]].{{cite book|last1=Noam|first1=Eli M.|title=Who Owns the World's Media?: Media Concentration and Ownership around the World|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, U.K.|isbn=9780199987238|oclc=883747287|page=960|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BCHuCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA960&lpg=PA960&dq=Yossi+Maiman&source=bl&ots=xecgxAo89E&sig=yQxBuP4J-lRknGu4FE-fWecRI_A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiz_KL1uOzPAhUMJMAKHRsRDbU4HhDoAQgeMAE#v=onepage&q=Yossi%20Maiman&f=false}} However, he divested from the channel in 2009.{{cite news|title=Yossi Maiman announces end of financial backing to Channel 10|url=http://www.jpost.com/Breaking-News/Yossi-Maiman-announces-end-of-financial-backing-to-Channel-10|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=July 13, 2009}} Additionally, Maiman served as the chairman of [[Eltek (Israeli company)|Eltek]], a manufacturer of [[printed circuit board]]s (publicly traded on the [[NASDAQ]] as "ELTK"), and [[Gadot (Israeli company)|Gadot]]. He is a shareholder of the [[East Mediterranean Gas Company]].{{cite news|last1=Gueta|first1=Jasmin|title=Maiman Tells Court His Assets Include 2 Yachts and 4 Homes|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/maiman-tells-court-his-assets-include-2-yachts-and-4-homes.premium-1.469288|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=Haaretz|date=October 11, 2012}} Maiman is the owner of [[Ecoteva Consulting]], a real estate development and rental company in [[Peru]].{{cite news|title=Josef Maiman sobre Ecoteva: "Es una manera de atacar a Alejandro Toledo"|url=http://larepublica.pe/politica/359531-josef-maiman-sobre-ecoteva-es-una-manera-de-atacar-alejandro-toledo|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=La República|date=August 9, 2015|quote="Ecoteva no le compra casas a Alejandro, sino para ser dueño de la propiedad, para alquilarla, quizás venderla con alguna plusvalía. Entre Toledo y yo no pasó nada, cuando hago una inversion lo hago bajo una razón social, no lo hago con mi nombre. Me acusan de lavado, pero lo último que he lavado ha sido mi ropa de baño", explicó, en entrevista al programa 'Sin peros en la lengua'.}} The company was founded in 2009 or 2011.{{cite news|title=Caso Ecoteva: declaraciones de Maiman contradicen las de Toledo y Karp|url=http://elcomercio.pe/politica/gobierno/caso-ecoteva-declaraciones-maiman-contradicen-toledo-karp-noticia-1662796|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=[[El Comercio (Peru)|El Comercio]]|date=November 22, 2013}} After former president [[Alejandro Toledo]] was indicted on allegations of corruption over the purchase of property via the company in 2013, whereby he might have taken bribes from the Brazilian companies [[Camargo Corrêa]] and [[Odebrecht]] for the construction of the [[Interoceanic Highway]],{{cite news|last1=Post|first1=Colin|title=Peru: former President Toledo to face trial for money laundering|url=http://perureports.com/2016/04/22/peru-former-president-toledo-go-trial-money-laundering/|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=Peru Reports|date=April 22, 2016}} the company was accused of [[money laundering]] via an offshore company based in [[Costa Rica]]; the [[Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority]] said the money went from [[Confiado International Corp]], a Panama-based company, to Costa Rica.{{cite news|last1=Romero|first1=César|title=Denuncian a Toledo, su esposa, su amigo Maiman y su ex seguridad Dan On|url=http://larepublica.pe/28-03-2015/denuncian-a-toledo-su-esposa-su-amigo-maiman-y-su-ex-seguridad-dan-on|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=La República|date=March 28, 2015|quote=Eva Fernenbug y Josef Maiman y la Cooperación Internacional Suiza han indicado que ese dinero provenía de cuentas en ese país de la empresa Confiado International Corp, que pasaron por Panamá, hasta llegar a Costa Rica.}} By 2015, Maiman responded by saying he was the victim of a [[smear campaign]]. The two men, alongside Tolerado's wife, [[Eliane Karp]], and three others, were summoned to court in 2016. During the trial, the prosecutor, Marco Cárdenas, suggested Maiman's [[financial privacy]] should be lifted to complete his investigation.{{cite news|title=Ecoteva: exfiscal a cargo recomienda levantar secreto bancario de Josef Maiman|url=http://larepublica.pe/politica/762205-ecoteva-exfiscal-cargo-recomienda-levantar-secreto-bancario-de-josef-maiman|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=La República|date=April 23, 2016}} Maiman served as the honorary consul of Israel to [[Peru]] and the Special Ambassador of Israel to [[Turkmenistan]]. He serves on the board of governors of [[Tel Aviv University]].{{cite web|title=Tel Aviv University Governors Roll|url=https://english.tau.ac.il/tau_governors_roll|website=Tel Aviv University|accessdate=October 21, 2016}} ==Personal life== Maiman is married, and he has three children. He resides in [[Herzliya]], Israel, where he owns two properties, one of which is in [[Herzliya Pituah]]. He also owns apartments in Miami and New York in the United States, and two yachts, one of which he sold in 2012.{{cite news|last1=Barkat|first1=Amiram|title=Yossi Maiman puts yacht up for sale|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000748946|accessdate=October 21, 2016|work=Globes|date=May 15, 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maiman, Yossi}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Israeli people of Polish-Jewish descent]] [[Category:People from Herzliya]] [[Category:Children of Holocaust survivors]] [[Category:University of Texas at El Paso alumni]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:Israeli company founders]] [[Category:Israeli chief executives]] [[Category:Peruvian businesspeople]] [[Category:1946 births]]
